Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding an inaccurate late payment report on my credit reportsTransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX from M & T Bank Under 15 U.S.

Code 1637 ( b ), creditors are required to provide periodic statements to consumers at least 21 days before a payment due date, giving adequate notice to ensure timely payments. In my case, I did not receive my statement within the required timeframe,
which may have led to the late designation on my account. 
Based on my records, I have consistently made payments on time and have not been late. 
Therefore, I believe the " late payment '' notation on my account is inaccurate and unjust. 

I respectfully request that my credit report be updated to reflect " paid as agreed '' and " never late '' for this account. Please investigate this matter and assist in correcting this discrepancy to ensure my credit history accurately reflects my payment record. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
My wife and I purchased a sectional from Rooms to Go approximately 3 years ago. They had a promotion of no interest on a 5 year payment plan. Our payment was $ XXXX which we have always been paid on time to Synchrony. 
Synchrony decided to change certain policies regarding paper statements that we were not aware of. They claim it was written in our statement in XXXX but we never saw it. Since we knew our payments would always be {$57.00} a month we did not notice they were adding a paper statement fee of {$1.00} per month to our payment beginning in XXXX. Therefore our XXXX statement was {$58.00} instead of {$57.00}. 
When we realized in XXXX that we had a {$90.00} statement, my wife called regarding the extra fees. They explained that we did not pay the total amount in XXXX of {$58.00} and were being assessed a {$30.00} late fee for the unpaid balance of {$1.00}. 
My wife agreed to pay the 2 months paper fee for XXXX and XXXX ( {$3.00} ) but asked synchrony to forgive the late fees. It was her understanding that this was approved. She remembers asking the operator " So I just need to pay you {$4.00}? '' My wife also agreed to stop the paper statements and have them sent by email. She did not know that Synchrony would be sending the email statements to XXXX 's address so did not know that Synchrony was still adding late fees on to our payment. 
She continued paying {$57.00} each month but Synchrony is saying we now owe {$140.00}. ( {$88.00} in fees ). My wife and I talked with Synchrony today and they insist we must pay these penalty charges. We offered to pay off the entire balance of the sectional but are not willing to pay penalty charges. They refused to comply.

We feel that we have been wrongly charged of these fees for 2 reasons. We pay our bills online and have paid Synchrony {$57.00} a month for years. It is completely understandable that we would not know about the {$1.00} fee they randomly decided to add to our bill. Even though we felt this was unethical for a bank to just decide to add a fee to a customers bill, we agreed to pay the {$1.00} for 2 months and have our statements sent by email. 
The second reason is we are being charged late fees on previous late fees. This was supposedly cleared up by my wife 's initial phone call to Synchrony that the late fees would be removed if she paid the {$3.00} in added paper statement fees. {$4.00} was sent to Synchrony on XX/XX/year>. Therefore no extra money should be owed by us.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My checking account number ending in XXXX was closed by Wells Fargo on XX/XX/year>. The account was closed due to erroneous mishandling, proper direction and instructions from Well Fargo Bank. I have since filed several claims to have this issue corrected but Well Fargo refuses to comply with my requests. I have pointed to many facts about an email that was left out of the fact findings done by Wells Fargo and its employees. It seems many key items have been overlooked and unaddressed my the Well Fargo team itself, XXXX of which includes the balance that was on the account at the time of it being closed. After the account was closed, I asked Wells Fargo associates when to expect to receive the balance on the account, and I was told I would receive a check in XXXX business days. Because of the claim I filed and investigation immediately after the account closer, I was then told by a Wells Fargo associate handling my case that it would be XXXX business days. 
Needles to say, it is XX/XX/XXXX and I have yet to receive a check that represents the balance that was on account prior to closer. I have questioned Wells Fargo associates on many occasion during the account investigation process about the funds on the account but there has been no resolution. Its has been XXXX business days, and 80 days since my account has closed. I am very concerned about the banking practices that are being mismanaged at Well Fargo and the negligence that is being displayed by these actions, 12 CFR Part 337 Unsafe and Unsound Banking Practices points to exactly these actions and are illegal and unlawful. I am also seeking to assess penalties to Wells Fargo for negligence to preform its fiduciary responsibilities when it has been presented to them on several occasions in the situation. 
In conclusion, I want to make Wells Fargo Bank fully aware that Under the Federal Reserve Act Section 29 which states there are 3 tiers that Wells Fargo Bank will be assessed for violations under the provisions of this act. Under the First Tier any member bank, and any institution affiliated party with respect to such member bank who violates any provision of section 22, 23A, or 23B or any regulation issued pursuant thereto, shall forfeit and pay civil penalty of not more than {$5000.00} of each day during which such violation continues. The fiduciary responsibility of Wells Fargo in this matter can not be ignored and will not be ignored.

Consumer complaint narrative: Wells Fargo handled my debit card dispute for " merchandise/services not received '' completely incorrectly. I can clearly explain why in this complaint. This is in regards to Wells Fargo case number XXXX. The dispute was opened around XX/XX/XXXX. They denied my claim today on XX/XX/XXXX without ever sending it to the merchant 's bank and requesting any evidence or documentation. They should have done this according to XXXX guidelines as I already attempted to resolve this matter directly with the merchant. Wells Fargo is aware of this due to the signed forms they requested from me which I faxed back on XX/XX/XXXX. According to research on the internet, XXXX demands that the issuing bank requests supporting documentation or evidence from the merchant and/or merchant 's bank. If the merchant and/or merchant 's bank is unable to provide any supporting documents or evidence that they did provide the consumer then it should result in an automated reversal in favor of the consumer. However, Wells Fargo has told me the exact opposite of this. They are telling me that it is my responsibility to provide supporting documentation that I did not receive what I paid for. They said without this, they can not move forward with the dispute. I told them it was their responsibility as my bank to request that from the merchant, and that they have it backwards. The Wells Fargo Executive Customer Relation agent today I spoke to at XXXX told me that I need to call the claims team and request to have my claim reopened, and that I must provide documentation that I did NOT get what I paid for. Again, this is the exact opposite of how it works. I also tried to explain that the merchant was completely unresponsive and they have closed my account so I am unable to provide any sort of evidence that I did NOT receive what I paid for, even if that was my obligation ; which it is of course not my obligation. It is plain and clear that Wells Fargo handled my claim completely incorrectly and now I am suffering for their ignorance. Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, IL XXXX XX/XX/XXXX USAA XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
XXXX XXXX, Tx XXXX Subject : Official Request for Refund of Remaining Finance Charge Pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1666d and Related Consumer Rights To Whom It May Concern, This letter serves as my official request for the refund of the remaining portion of the finance charge due to me, XXXX XXXX, as a consumer, pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1666d and my 15 U.S.C. 1635 ( 4 ) right of rescission in connection with a consumer credit transaction.

Legal Basis for Refund Request Under 15 U.S.C. 1666d, creditors are required to : 1. Credit the amount of a credit balance to the consumers account, 2. Refund any remaining credit balance upon request, and 3. Perform this action in good faith. 

As part of this request, I assert my rights to the refund of all applicable credit balances associated with this account. 

Additionally, as defined by the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), a credit card under 15 U.S.C. 1602 ( k ) includes any card, plate, coupon book, or other credit device used for the purpose of obtaining money, property, labor, or services on credit. In this transaction, my Social Security card was used, and it falls within this statutory definition.

My Rights Under 15 U.S.C. 1666i As a credit card customer, I am further protected under 15 U.S.C. 1666i, which allows cardholders to assert claims and defenses in disputes arising from credit card transactions. This provision reinforces my right to a refund as a credit card customer under federal law. 

Supporting Documentation I have included relevant documentation and attachments to support my request. These include : Evidence of the transaction and credit balance with you financial data base. 
Consumer Credit Transaction loan aggreement with finance charge accurately showing amounts due. 


Request for Action Please consider this letter as my formal request to process a refund of the remaining finance charge or any other credit balance on my account. I trust USAA will act promptly and in good faith to address this matter. 

If further information or clarification ( ONLY ) is needed, please contact me at ( XXXX ) XXXX or XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a timely response and resolution. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Violations of 15 USC 1666d XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. ( XXXX ) misidentified the basis for the charge but failed to respond to XXXX requests for information about it. XXXX continued to seek payment and reported the debt as delinquent to credit agencies, despite XXXX protest. In doing so, XXXX admittedly violated multi- ple sections of the Fair Credit Billing Act ( FCBA ), 15 U.S.C . 16661666j. 
After unsuccessfully attempting to get a direct response from XXXX, XXXX and his wife filed this action in the District of Oregon, alleging inter alia claims under the FCBA and Oregons Unlawful Debt Collection Practices Act ( UDCPA ), Or. Rev. Stat. 646.639.643. The trial court dismissed the UDCPA claim and limited XXXX total recov- ery under the FCBA to {$1000.00}. 

Money Store Violations of 15 USC 166d The Second Circuit holds that loan assignees are not creditors for purposes of the TILAs credit balance refund provision. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ). The plaintiffs in this class-action lawsuit obtained mortgages from creditors who later assigned them to XXXX XXXX XXXX. The plaintiffs alleged that XXXX XXXX XXXX violated Section 165 of the TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1666d, by failing to refund credit balances on their accounts. The trial court dismissed the TILA claim. On appeal, the Second Circuit affirmed, holding that the TILA provision at issue only applies to creditors, which Section 103 ( g ) of the TILA defines in part as the person to whom the debt arising from the consumer credit transaction is initially payable on the face of the evidence of indebtedness or, if there is no such evidence of indebtedness, by agreement, 15 U.S.C. 1602 ( g ).
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Neither my caseworker nor I received any further clarification from the complex, and the matter was subsequently forwarded to collections without proper resolution. 

Once assigned to ProCollect, I received no written notification of the debt, nor was I afforded the opportunity to request verification of the debt as required under Colorado tenant laws and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). Despite multiple dispute attempts, ProCollect has not acknowledged or validated my requests. This unresolved and unsubstantiated debt is now adversely impacting my ability to secure safe and stable housing. 

I respectfully request immediate action to resolve this matter. Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Complaint Against CKS Prime Investments , LLC and XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXs I am filing a formal complaint against CKS Prime Investments , LLC and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX for improper debt collection practices, including violations of the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), Regulation Z, the Credit CARD Act, and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 

Context Background : On XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX XXXX I received a letter from XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  notifying me that my account ( ending in XXXX ) with an outstanding balance of {$1000.00} had been charged off and sold to CKS Prime Investments , LLC. 
CKS is now attempting to collect this debt, including {$700.00} in overlimit charges. I did not receive prior notice of these charges from XXXX, and the account number referenced by CKS does not match the account number originally provided by XXXX. 
Overlimit Charges : I did not opt in to permit transactions exceeding my credit limit, nor was I adequately informed about such charges. The imposition of overlimit fees without explicit consent may violate the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), 15 U.S.C. 1637 ( i ), and its implementing Regulation Z, 12 CFR Part 1026.56.

Statute of Limitations : The debt was charged off on XX/XX/year>, and the statute of limitations for collecting credit card debt in Texas is four years. Pursuing collection beyond this period may violate the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) and its implementing Regulation F, 12 CFR Part 1006.26.

Unreasonable Billing Cycle : CKS applied a XXXX billing cycle during a XXXX month, which gave me insufficient time to review my statement and make payments. This action led to overlimit and potentially late fees, which I believe violate TILA, Regulation Z, and FDCPA Section 1692f. 
Improper Service of Process : The process server who delivered the lawsuit papers failed to validate my identity, age, or residency at the address where service was attempted. This interaction was recorded for evidence. The process server only identified themselves as a process server without disclosing their affiliation, raising concerns about the validity of the service. 

This letter pertains to the debt associated with the account ending in 1455, for which CKS claims a balance of {$1000.00} ( {$320.00} actual credit card balance, plus {$700.00} in overlimit fees ). The following points require clarification and documentation : 1. Overlimit Fees and Lack of Consent : I did not opt in to allow transactions exceeding my credit limit, nor was I properly notified about overlimit fees. These actions violate TILA, 15 U.S.C. 1637 ( i ), and Regulation Z, 12 CFR Part 1026.56.

2. Statute of Limitations : The debt was charged off on XX/XX/year>, and Texass statute of limitations for collecting credit card debt is four years. CKSs actions may violate Regulation F, 12 CFR Part 1006.26, which prohibits time-barred collections. 
3. Unreasonable Billing Cycle : CKS imposed a XXXX billing cycle during a XXXX month, which I believe to be an unfair and deceptive practice under FDCPA Section 1692f and a violation of Regulation Z under TILA. 
4. Lack of Debt Validation and Misleading Practices : Upon receiving collection notices from CKS, I requested validation of the debt as required by FDCPA Section 1692g. However, CKS failed to provide adequate documentation or clear itemization of the charges. This lack of validation and misleading communication may violate FDCPA Section 1692e, which prohibits false or misleading representations. 
5. Improper Service of Process : The process server failed to properly identify themselves or verify my identity during the service of legal documents, raising concerns about the validity of the legal proceedings initiated by CKS.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this formal dispute against Zion Debt Holdings due to their fraudulent reporting of an account on my credit report, which I have never authorized or agreed to, and for which I have no legitimate obligation. I have never conducted business with Zion Debt Holdings, nor have I entered into any financial arrangement or credit agreement with this company. Their unauthorized reporting on my credit report constitutes a breach of privacy, causing significant and unjust harm to my credit score and adversely affecting both my business and personal financial endeavors.

Specific Violations : Privacy Violation : Zion Debt Holdings is reporting an account on my credit report without my knowledge or consent, in violation of privacy protections outlined in the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). Under the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681b, companies must have a legitimate and authorized reason to access or report information on a consumer 's credit file. Zion Debt Holdings has no such reason, as I have no legitimate account or relationship with them.

Negative Impact on Credit Score and Financial Harm : This fraudulent account has caused a substantial decrease in my credit score, directly affecting my ability to conduct business and pursue personal financial projects. The reporting of this unverified account has led to financial losses and reputational harm, as lenders now view my credit profile as less favorable, impacting my opportunities and standing.

FCRA Requirements and Due Diligence : Zion Debt Holdings has failed to comply with FCRA mandates requiring accurate and verified reporting of consumer information. According to the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ), all information supplied to credit bureaus must be accurate and verifiable. Zion Debt Holdings has disregarded these requirements by reporting false information without substantiating the accounts legitimacy or providing proof of my responsibility for this debt. 
Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) Violations : If Zion Debt Holdings has accessed my information or pursued collection actions, they may also be in violation of the FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. 1692, which prohibits deceptive and misleading practices in debt collection. Reporting an account with no valid grounds or contractual basis constitutes misleading and harmful behavior, prohibited under the FDCPA.

Resolution Requested : Immediate Investigation and Removal : I request that the CFPB conduct an investigation into Zion Debt Holdings for their unauthorized and fraudulent reporting practices and demand the immediate removal of this account from my credit report. 
Cease and Desist : Zion Debt Holdings must cease any further collection activities or credit reporting actions related to this unauthorized account and must not share or access my private information again without verifiable cause. 
Financial and Reputational Remediation : I seek full remediation for the harm caused to my credit and reputation, including any damages resulting from this false reporting. 
Thank you for your attention to this serious matter. I trust that you will hold Zion Debt Holdings accountable for these unlawful actions and ensure the necessary correction is made to my credit file.
Company public response: Company disputes the facts presented in the complaint

Issue: Took or threatened to take negative or legal action
Sub-issue: Sued you in a state where you do not live or did not sign for the debt
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have complaint which includes two parts, and each has several " deceptive practices '' associated with it. 

Part I. The first has to do with suing me without providing sufficient evidence ( no document signed by either party was ever presented yet the judge initiated a lawsuit ).

Case Summary : I submitted this to the state bar of Texas but my lawsuit has still been moved to a pre-trial hearing on XXXX XXXX. 

XXXX. A lawsuit was filed on me on XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and I received the paperwork on or around XXXX XXXX. The plaintiff was XXXX XXXX XXXX and the suit was filed in XXXX XXXX XXXX of the Peace XXXX. The judge is named XXXX XXXX. 

XXXX suit is about the purchase of a laptop from Best Buy, with financing being provided by Citibank. The debt was sold by Citibank to XXXX XXXX XXXX. The paperwork filed included only an invoice which was for an amount far greater than the original purchase price and cited an interest rate of 30 %. There was no copy of a contract included in the paperwork, nor was anything signed by either party included in the paperwork. Based upon this, I have grave concerns that literally anyone could walk into a court, produce a phony invoice, and be granted a lawsuit against me ( or anyone else for that matter ). This lawsuit, XXXX, is based on insufficient evidence ( no signed contract or supporting documentation ). 

XXXX. Because of this lawsuit, the door was opened to many attorneys for further actions. And despite the lack of evidence, multiple attorneys ( at least ten ) solicited me via threatening letters. Indeed, had I accepted a deal offered me by XXXX XXXX XXXX, I would have paid close to twice the original purchase price without any essential evidence of wrongdoing ever having been presented because of this attempted intimidation. 

XXXX. Allegations : o Coercive Solicitation : Attorneys threatened liens, garnishment, and severe financial consequences to induce me to hire them. 

o Unreasonable Fees : One attorney demanded {$750.00} and claimed they could " negotiate '' the case down, without ever having even talked with XXXX XXXX XXXX. Not only did this firm presume my guilt without ever asking me whether I wished to plead innocent, the amount projected would have still resulted in me losing over twice the original amount of the dispute. Most of the money would have been paid to the two lawyers involved, and I suspect collusion, perhaps even based upon previous experience, is possible. 

o Potential Collusion : The presiding judge granted the lawsuit despite insufficient evidence. I suspect possible collusion between the attorneys and the plaintiff or judge, given the swift approval and subsequent solicitations. I have written my own motion to dismiss I am not a lawyer - but I fear submitting it to this precinct for I do not believe that I can get a fair hearing from this judge given the above. 

5. Supporting Evidence : o I submitted copies of 2 threatening solicitation letters.

o I also submitted the paperwork I received via the law suit. No signed coument, by either party, was included in the paperwork.

6. Relief Requested : o Investigate the attorneys conduct for potential violations of professional ethics.

o Determine if these attorneys have a history of filing baseless lawsuits or engaging in coercive practices. 
o Investigate whether these practices, taken together, constitute extortion.

Part II. The actual transaction.

a. ) The use of credit in this transaction is absolutely inappropriate for me and should never have occurred. I have purchased several laptops previously through Best Buy and paid them all off, but never once was any transaction accompanied by a credit card. Furthermore, I had enough money in my bank account to purchase this item several times over, without any payments. Citibank provided the financing, and at an egregiously high ( 30 % ) rate according to the legal filing. 

In addition, I do not even own a credit card! I make all of my purchases for my auto, my residence, my insurance, etc. literally everything that I purchase - through my checking account and one debit card. I think I may have one experience in my life with a credit card - a Macys card which, upon finding a disgustingly high rate of interest I was to be charged, I cut up and destroyed. In sum, I question why this abrupt change in the terms of a transaction was ever appropriate for me. 

b. ) Even if there is a contract regarding this transaction, it can not capture all of the conditions present at the time the transaction took place. Again, I will suggest that several deceptive practices were in place. 

b1. As mentioned above, having never experienced a credit transaction with this firm, I had no reason to expect that credit was being offered. It was a deceptive practice to offer one under these circumstances.

b2. The explanation at the time of sale was also inadequate and I never had knowledge that a credit transaction was being offered. As I recall, the salesman at Best Buy conducting this transaction offered me a credit card as a perquisite perhaps as a reward to a repeat buyer. In fact, the way I remember it being presented to me was that it was a reward for my continued purchase of laptops at Best Buy and, therefore, could have been applied to any future purchases. Had I known that the transaction in question was to be subject to additional interest charges based upon some credit extension, I would never have agreed to this purchase. 

b3. My subsequent behaviors are very consistent with this state of knowledge. I distinctly remember leaving Best But that day in XX/XX/XXXX thinking that I had just made a purchase for which monthly payments of about {$35.00} would be assessed. And, as I understood the transaction, interest was to be recovered in that consistent monthly payment. Subsequently, I earnestly made 17 months of {$35.00} payments. I made them for 17 months on time and without fail. 

It may be that at some point in time after the purchase, Citibank may have attempted to contact me. I literally do not know. I had no reason to respond, even if they did attempt to contact me, as I was secure in the knowledge that I was making my {$35.00} per month payments. I did not anticipate any additional charges and would not have been seeking them out. 

After I had made 17 payments, I attempted to contact Citibank, not to find out about any interest rates, but to find out when the payments would end. My payments totalled {$590.00}, a substantial part of the original purchase price ( think about it - a relatively low end ordinary laptop! ) Though I do not have the exact numbers in front of me, I believe that those 17 payments constituted most of the initial price. However, I learned then that their interest payments had not only obviated all of my monthly payments but contributed to a rise in my account which made the balance close to the original purchase price. In other words, I had been paying for 17 months, but my balance was close to the original purchase price with which I began. Now, a year and half after that time, the additional interest charges they have tacked on certainly exceed the original purchase price. This seemed ( and still seems ) absolutely absurd to me. Therefore, I stopped payments on this purchase. 

b4. The Citibank customer service was terrible and they withheld information about what and how I was being charged from me! After 17 months, when I contacted their customer service department, I asked for access to a website where I could see the individual charges and transactions, but that was denied. They offered to send me, by mail, a copy of this evidence, but I never received it. To this day, I have not seen a detailed record of what they did or how they did it, yet they see fit to bring a lawsuit against me. I also offered to pay off the principal over the phone whatever was remaining of the original purchase price after subtracting my payments- but they refused to consider this as well. At this point, I gave up even trying to discuss this matter with Citibank. 

b5. After this contact, Citibank harassed me for two solid months every day dunning me for the payments. This harassment was conducted systematically and deliberately and was manifested as daily text messages on my phone.

b6. Rather than ever addressing the original cause of the problem, Citibank chose to sell this to another firm. In doing so, they absolve themselves from further responsibility, and without ever addressing the original problem. There are mechanisms by which Citibank and Best Buy could collect information from customers interviews, focus groups, customer service reps, etc. However, these two firms are deliberately absolving themselves of any responsibility for correcting errors in the transaction that they committed. They choose to punish rather than listen to customers! By doing so -they forego the opportunity for improvement in this aspect of transaction for a large number of transactions, -they escalate costs for everyone. Those costs not only rise is a non-linear manner, they fall most heavily on me, an individual, rather than on the deep-pocketed firms who have caused this debacle. 
-they also avoid the negative reputation that might result as some heavy-handed tactics ( e.g., the lawsuit and threats of garnishment and liens ) seemed to commence only after they sold the suit. 

b7. In retrospect, it also appears to me that these firms were attempting to run up the price of the transaction onto which they attach interest. There was a {$200.00} charge for a one-year XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX on a new laptop, for which the maintenance contract should not have been necessary ) which was included in the purchase price and subject to the high interest rates as well. 

In sum, I never needed, wanted, requested or even knew of the interest that was to be charted on this purchase. I left Best Buy thinking that my monthly payments of {$35.00} included an interest rate, not that I would be subject to additional payments into which enormous interest rates were incorporated. 

Finally, I believe that it is also ridiculous that the firm XXXX XXXX is asking to be compensated for any additional charges here. Had this transaction been handled properly up front by Citibank and Best Buy, there would be no additional costs. That Citibank and Best Buy are not incurring them is even more evidence that they are avoiding the responsibility that inheres in legitimate business transactions, and I can see no reason for any additional costs to be paid by me. 

I am not guilty of whatever charges are being brought against me, and I should not be charged anything further by these firms. I would also like to remind the CFBP that it takes time and effort to formulate my own defense and to communicate it, and this case has caused me emotional distress as well. 

XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Unjust Charges and Credit Card Mismanagement by Best Buy and Citibank Dear CFPB Team, I am writing to formally file a complaint against Best Buy and Citibank regarding unfair credit card charges and the negative impact on my credit score resulting from their actions. 

Background : 1. In XXXX I purchased a television from Best Buy over the phone. During the transaction, the Best Buy representative offered me a store credit card with a limit exceeding {$4000.00}, which was managed by Citibank. I agreed to this and provided my necessary information. 
2. I explicitly requested that the full cost of the television, approximately {$1200.00}, be charged to the credit card immediately upon purchase. Instead, they processed only the minimum monthly payment, without informing me or obtaining my consent for this arrangement. 
3. At no point during the transaction or afterward did I receive any documentation from Best Buy or Citibank detailing the terms of the credit card, including interest rates, grace periods, or repayment policies. 

Discovery of the Issue : Over two years later, I discovered that Citibank was still charging me monthly payments, despite my understanding that I had already paid off the original {$1200.00} charge. When I contacted Citibank to investigate : They informed me that I had exceeded the promotional period for interest-free payments and was being charged retroactive interest. 
I explained that I had requested the {$1200.00} charge to be paid in full at the time of purchase and suggested they review the call records to confirm my statement. However, they claimed that the call records were no longer available. 
To make matters worse, after the issue arose, Citibank sent me a backlog of invoices and statements covering the previous two years. These documents were never sent to me during the original period, depriving me of any opportunity to notice or address the problem earlier. 

My Attempts to Resolve the Issue : 1. I offered to settle the matter by paying an additional {$200.00} as a goodwill gesture, but Citibank refused. 
2. They subsequently closed my credit card account, reported me to the credit bureaus as a delinquent account, and significantly damaged my credit score. This has negatively impacted my employment opportunities. 
3. Afterward, third-party collection agencies began contacting me for payment, suggesting that Citibank sold the debt without resolving the dispute. 

My Request : I firmly believe I have been treated unfairly and subjected to predatory lending practices. The lack of transparency regarding the credit card terms, refusal to investigate the original phone call, and unjust reporting to credit bureaus have caused significant financial and professional harm. 

I respectfully request CFPBs assistance in : 1. Investigating this matter thoroughly.

2. Holding Best Buy and Citibank accountable for their actions.

3. Rectifying the damage to my credit score and ensuring that this debt is resolved fairly. 

Thank you for your time and attention. I look forward to your assistance in resolving this issue.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently received a letter from Pinnacle a debt collection agency listing their address as XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, CA XXXX. Their phone number is listed as ( XXXX ) XXXX. 

They asserted that I owed a delinquent maintenance obligation to XXXX XXXX XXXX. At first, this name did not ring a bell. After further research, I discovered that my late father, who died in XX/XX/XXXX, who has the same name as me ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX had purchased a one-week timeshare at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX , SC. After he passed away, we set up a trust to manage the affairs of my mother, who moved to Louisiana in XXXX. The trustee attorney, XXXX XXXX of XXXX, Louisiana, handled her legal affairs. XXXX XXXX was not explicitly called out in my fathers probate documents. During the time he owned it, neither he nor my mother ever used it. She did not know that he had purchased a timeshare. 

However, we started receiving notices on whether we wanted to rent out the timeshare, which we responded to affirmatively. However, even after the rental, we received notices that my father owed a maintenance fee of {$100.00} each year, which the trust paid. I was never associated with the property or had it transferred to my name. 

After my mother passed away in XXXX, I asked XXXX XXXX to dispose of the timeshare agreement as part of her probate process. He was not convinced that it had any force, given that it was in my fathers name, and he was deceased. We received no other letters from XXXX XXXX after her probate. XXXX XXXX passed away in XXXX. 

I thought about contacting Pinnacle directly. However, I thought that this might be a scam. I receive many crank phone calls from numbers where I am urged to contact them to Keep my electricity from being turned off, take advantage of a loan offer, or a fake job offer. Although none of these entreaties apply, there is often an element that comes across as truthful. 

In this case, if XXXX had been trying to collect for this long against me, it should have appeared in my credit reports. I ran all three of the major credit agency reports, and nothing came up. When I checked the XXXX XXXX website, it indicated that the facility was closed. 

I will assume that this letter represents a more sophisticated form of letter SCAM and ignore it. However, I thought you might be interested. The scam phone calls on other topics ( often the same message from continuously changing phone numbers ) and emails are increasingly numerous. 

A copy of the letter is attached.
Company public response: Company believes the complaint is the result of a misunderstanding

Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE OF DISPUTE ; DEMAND FOR VALIDATION AND PROOF OF CLAIM To Whom it May Concern Your company is illegally trying to collect and is furnishing false items that violates my consumer rights and FDCPA and FCRA. Be advised that your claim is disputed. Debt validation has to be provided in accordance with the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, 15 USC {$1600.00} and as amended by adding the following new Title 8 US {$800.00} et seq., and the Fair Credit Billing Act, 15 USC. {$1600.00} et seq. All of which work in conjunction with each other, including the Truth In Lending Act ( TILA ) 15 USC 1601 et seq. It is not now, nor has it ever been, my intention to avoid paying any alleged obligation that is lawfully owed by the Claimant. In order to make arrangements to pay an obligation which may be lawfully owed, please document and verify the " debt '' by complying, in good faith, with this request for validation and return it to me, within thirty ( 30 ) days of receipt of this letter. 
This is was NOT a request for " verification '' or proof of Claimant mailing address or copies of bank statements you could find, but a request for VALIDATION and PROOF OF CLAIM made pursuant to the above named Titles and Sections. I respectfully request that your offices provide Claimant with competent evidence as per the attached " Declaration and Proof of Claim '' that I have any legal obligation to pay you the unsubstantiated alleged debt. Furthermore you shall cease all verbal communication. No phone calls to the Claimant. At this time I will also inform you that if your offices have reported invalidated information to any of the 3 major Credit Bureaus, such as, XXXX, XXXX and XXXX prior to validation and proof of claim of the disputed debt, this action might constitute fraud under both Federal and State Laws. Due to this fact ; if any negative mark is found on any of Claimant credit reports by your company or the company that you represent I will not hesitate in bringing legal action against you and your client for the following : - Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act - Violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act Defamation of Character - Violation of United States Code TITLE 18 PART 1 CHAPTER 63 1341 ( Mail Fraud ) This debt is considered to be invalid and all collection of this alleged account be stopped until I receive proper validation and your offices provide Claimant with proof of claim of the disputed debt. Your offices have 30 days to produce the required documentation in accordance with FTC guidelines. During this validation period and proof of claim, if any action is taken which could be considered detrimental to any of Claimant credit reports, said action will be considered a " dishonor '' and cause the self-executing contract portion of this notice to be implemented. This includes any listing any information to a credit reporting repository that could be inaccurate or invalidated. If your offices fail to respond to this validation and proof of claim request within 30 days from the date of your receipt, all references to this account must be deleted and completely removed from Claimant credit file and a copy of such deletion request shall be sent to Claimant immediately. Title 8 USC {$800.00}. Validation of debts [ 15 USC 1692g ] ( b ) If the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period described in subsection ( a ) that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor, the debt collector shall cease collection of the debt, or any disputed portion thereof, until the debt collector obtains verification of the debt or any copy of a judgment, or the name and address of the original creditor, and a copy of such verification or judgment, or name and address of the original creditor, is mailed to the consumer by the debt collector. XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX : VERIFICATION. Confirmation of correctness, truth, or authenticity, by affidavit, oath, or deposition. RULING 1002 - Requirement of the original An original writing, recording, or photograph is required in order to prove its content unless these rules or a federal statute provides otherwise. Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted a dispute letter to SafeRent Solutions , LLC. on XX/XX/XXXX. I noticed inaccuracies on my consumer report through SafeRent Solutions.

As a consumer reporting agency 15 U.S.C. $ 1681a ( f ), you are governed by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 'FCRA '' ). 15 U.S.C. 1681, et seq., which protects consumers from inaccurate, outdated, or invalidated information reporting of their consumer file. The FCRA states that it's the consumer reporting agency 's responsibility to ensure that all information contained within consumer files is accurate and free from errors. 
Your company is regularly engaged in the business of assembling, evaluating, and disbursing information concerning consumers for the purpose of furnishing consumer reports, as defined in 15 U.S.C. {$1600.00} ( d ), to third parties.

According to federal law, you are required to comply with the requirements imposed under the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., including but not limited to : 1 ) follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information in the consumer report, as required by 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). This section imposes a high and often disregarded standard on consumer reporting agencies. See, e.g., XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX. XXXX, XXXX ) ( breaking down the requirements of 1681e ( b ), and explaining that " assure ' means 'to make sure or certain : put beyond all doubt, '' ' [ maximum ' means the 'greatest in quantity or highest degree attainable [, ] ' and 'possible ' means something falling within the bounds of what may be done, occur or be conceived. '' ( quoting XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
2 ) comply with the investigation requirements, as required by 15 U.S.C. 1681i.

3 ) should not provide consumer files to companies without determining that these companies had a permissible purpose to obtain consumer files pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681b.

4 ) provide consumer file pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681g ; 5 ) et seq.

Accordingly, I request your company to provide verifiable documentary proof ( e.g., original consumer contract or similar proof bearing my wet ink signature on it ) you have on file of accounts/items listed below. 

Under the FCRA, if you do not provide documented and verifiable proof, you must remove all unverified, invalid, derogatory information from my consumer report. 

Upon completion of your investigation, please send a detailed description of the procedures used to determine the accuracy of the accounts/items XXXX XXXX disputing, as well as the name and contact information of the agent conducting the said investigation in case further communication

Please consider this letter a formal dispute of the validity of the alleged debt. Until I receive satisfactory documentation, I request that you cease reporting this account to any credit reporting agencies per 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( c ).

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I expect a response within thirty days of receiving this letter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

When attempting to make my next payment I could no longer access my account. I called Freedom Mortgage customer service in XXXX of XXXX  and they informed me that they had stopped access due to privacy concerns regarding the previous mortgage owners information apparently still in that account. They also informed me that they were working to resolve the problem. I have since called numerous times and given a case number of XXXX with no outlook for resolution. 
The Freedom Mortgage phone payment method is absolutely the most tedious and frustrating interface I have ever had to deal with. It is almost as if they are hoping folks using the system will XXXX it up and miss a payment. I once again called today and was told that there was no outlook for resolution. I googled searched this issue and to no surprise it seems that anyone with an assumed mortgage involving Freedom Mortgage is having the very same issue. While there isn't a single, explicit law stating mortgage companies must provide web or application access to a mortgage account, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) regulations under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) essentially mandate this by requiring lenders to provide borrowers with accessible and accurate information regarding their loan details, which typically includes online access to account information through a secure portal. The Freedom Mortgage phone system does provide accessibility to my mortgage information but again it is the absolute worst phone interface I have ever used and it obviously does not allow for electronically copying and storing the information as one needs to be able to do these days. This can not be a huge software development effort to fix and really do not understand Freedom Mortgages reluctance to fix this issue.

In accordance with the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I request the following information : 1. The name and address of the original creditor and the current creditor.

2. Verification of the debt amount you are seeking to collect, including evidence that a contract exists creating the amount you claim is owed.

3. Documentation of all assignments showing the transfer of the debt from the original creditor to the current creditor.

5. Documentation showing the assignments of the debt from the original creditor to the secured trust and then back to the original creditor. 
XXXX. Chain of XXXX XXXX. Assignment of Contract Please cease and desist from collecting on this debt until you have provided validation of the debt. 
Additionally, I request that you do not access my credit report or report anything to my credit bureaus. I dispute the validity of this debt amount, and this dispute should be reflected on my credit report if you have already reported this debt.

Permissible Purpose Please state your permissible purpose for accessing my credit information. I dispute your right to do so.

Notification to Other Collectors I dispute that I owe this debt to you. Should you transfer this debt to another collector, please inform them of my dispute regarding the validity of this debt.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I had recently moved to XXXX, XXXX XXXX and work at the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. On XX/XX/year>, after having dinner with my family at XXXX XXXX in XXXX, we were walking out of the restaurant and a man approached us in a suit and name tag. He said he worked for XXXX XXXX and asked if I had signed up for my 20 % off coupon. I said I wasnt interested but he was being persistent and said it would only take a few minutes. He led me to the XXXX XXXX XXXX row of ATMs and said I could sign up on the ATM, and I just needed to use my bank card ( in XXXX XXXX many different types of transactions are done through the ATM so this did not seem unusual to me ). 

I inserted my XXXX XXXX  XXXX debit card and logged into the ATM. Another man approached and was trying to distract me. I started to get the sense that something was not right and I tried to retrieve my ATM card but it was stuck in the machine. I took out my citibank credit card and tried to dislodge my ATM card with it but it did not work ( I did not insert it fully into the ATM machine ). The second man walked away and the first man was pretending to assist me. I told him that I worked for the XXXX XXXX and was calling the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX to assist he then fled. 

Knowing that my bank card was stuck in the machine, I immediately deactivated it through the app. Subsequently, a number of charges were blocked totaling close to {$7000.00}. Unfortunately, I did not cancel my citibank card because since it didnt go into the ATM machine, I didnt think it was compromised. I only realized it was compromised after I got an alert from Citibank for potential fraud ( charge for {$2500.00} for XXXX XXXX ). Unfortunately, their first transaction of {$1700.00} for XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX went through. This does not appear to be a legitimate company and I did not authorize the transaction. I disputed this claim through the fraud department and was told since I was still in possession of the card it was not fraud? Clearly this is a skimming scam and I did not authorize the purchase. Had Citibank performed even a cursory review, they would have realized this was fraud. 

Based on the advice of a very helpful Citibank customer service rep, I then tried to dispute the claim with Citibank as a charge dispute ( instead of fraud which it is ), and then denied the dispute again on XX/XX/year> - stating That once the credit card number is given to merchant and a transaction has taken place, the merchant terms and conditions apply.

Again, this was FRAUD and was subject to a skimming scam from a reputable ATM machine. I never gave my credit card information up to engage in a transaction with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

If a consumer notifies a debt collector in writing that the consumer refuses to pay a debt or that the consumer wishes the debt collector to cease further communication with the consumer, the debt collector shall not communicate further with the consumer with respect to such debt, except ( XXXX ) to advise the consumer that the debt collectors further efforts are being terminated ; ( XXXX ) to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor may invoke specified remedies which are ordinarily invoked by such debt collector or creditor; or ( XXXX ) where applicable, to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor intends to invoke a specified remedy. 
If such notice from the consumer is made by mail, notification shall be complete upon receipt. 
Under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), specifically 15 U.S. Code 1692c ( c ), consumers have the right to request that a debt collector ceases further communication regarding a debt. When a consumer sends a written request or informs the collector that they refuse to pay, the collector is legally obligated to stop contacting the consumer, with only a few exceptions. Heres a breakdown of what this provision entails and how it might impact your credit profile : XXXX. Purpose of XXXX ( c ) : This section allows consumers to regain control over communications from debt collectors. Once a collector receives a written cease communication request or a clear statement of refusal to pay, they must comply by stopping most forms of contact. 
XXXX. Exceptions to the Rule : After a XXXX ( c ) request, a collector can still contact the consumer to : Inform them that collection efforts will cease. 
Notify them of any specific legal actions the collector or creditor intends to take. 
Confirm or provide additional information regarding the debt. 
XXXX. How XXXX ( c ) Impacts Credit Reporting : Requesting a cessation of communication does not directly remove a debt from your credit report. It stops communication but does not erase the debt or affect its validity. However, if a debt collector violates this provision, you may have grounds to dispute the debt if it continues to appear on your report or if communication persists in violation of the law. 
XXXX. Challenging Debt Legitimacy : Although XXXX ( c ) does not remove a debt from a credit profile, you can dispute inaccurate or outdated debt entries separately under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). If successful, such a dispute can lead to the debt being corrected or removed. 
XXXX. Steps if Debt Remains on Credit Profile After Request : You may need to submit disputes to the credit reporting agencies, providing any evidence of the written XXXX ( c ) request. This can bolster your case for removal if the debt remains inaccurately listed as unresolved or active in collections. 
This section ensures peace from collection calls but doesnt erase the record of debt ; however, it provides leverage if the collector violates these rules. 











XXXX

Subject : Failure to Disclose Notice of Sale and GAP Insurance Credits by Flagship Credit Acceptance I am writing to formally notify the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) regarding the refusal of Flagship Credit Acceptance to provide essential disclosures related to the repossession and subsequent sale of my vehicle. Despite my repeated requests, XXXX XXXX XXXX has failed to disclose the following critical information : 1. **Notice of Sale** : The lender has not provided the required notice detailing the sale of the repossessed vehicle, including the sale price, as mandated by applicable state laws. 

2. XXXX XXXX XXXX : I have requested information regarding any amounts credited from my Guaranteed Asset Protection ( GAP ) insurance that were applied towards the sale price of the vehicle and the remaining loan balance. This information is crucial for understanding my financial obligations following the repossession. 

Under California law, lenders are obligated to provide a detailed accounting of the sale of repossessed vehicles, including the sale price and any credits from GAP insurance [ [ 3 ] ] The lack of transparency in this matter not only violates my rights as a consumer but also undermines the regulatory framework designed to protect borrowers from unfair practices. 

I urge the CFPB to investigate this matter and take appropriate action to ensure that XXXX XXXX XXXX complies with its legal obligations. The failure to disclose this information is detrimental to my financial well-being and may constitute a violation of the Consumer Financial Protection Act.

Issue: Problems at the end of the loan or lease
Sub-issue: Problem when attempting to purchase vehicle at the end of the lease
Consumer complaint narrative:
The lease on my XXXX XXXX XXXX ended on XX/XX/XXXX. This was also the date of my last lease payment. I was exploring whether to buy out my lease or have a dealer lease buyout. Every time I would contact US Bank Leasing, the buyout amount would be different. Even times where the I'd talk to two different representatives on the same day ; the buyout amount would be different. After multiple phone calls and a lot of mixed results, I decided it would be easiest to just deal with a dealership buyout, even though this was costing me extra money ( US Bank Leasing likes to charge dealerships more than they do the consumer ). 

In order to move this process along faster, I paid off my lease on XX/XX/XXXX. However, as I later found out, US Bank Leasing would not apply my early payment until the XXXX and if I terminated before the XXXX, I would be charged an 'Early Termination Fee '. I then decided to wait to turn in my dealership buy out on XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX They provided me with a lease buy out quote and applied this to my deal on a new vehicle. Upon signing documents, I then learned that the lease buy out through the dealership did not include sales tax, whereas my own personal buyout would include this amount. This would be another {$1500.00} lost. Since the deal was all but done, I decided to sign the deal and be done with US Bank Leasing. However, apparently this was still far too simple.

US Bank Leasing decided to remove another payment, that was not owed from my checking account for {$610.00}. I called them about getting this overpayment refunded, to which they told me they would submit a request for a cashier 's check be sent to me. This could take up to 7-10 business days to receive. After waiting 10+ business days, I called to check on the status of my refund check, to which I found out that they reversed the refund check because it was needed to satisfy my lease buy out. The lease buyout number they provided to the dealership INCLUDED my own personal overpayment so they would now need to use that money to satisfy my lease buy out. Essentially, allowing the dealership access to the refund on my account. No contact attempt was made on US Banks behalf to find out if this was acceptable, this refund amount was not provided to my dealership, US Bank Leasing just took it upon themselves to quote the dealership a lower buyout amount using my money.

After talking with three different representatives today, XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX I'm told this is something that happens frequently. They just give their costumer 's money to dealerships and hose their customers. I asked them why a simple policy change to NEVER provide dealership a customer 's credit/refund would be so hard, to which I received no response. Now, I am left receiving no vehicle sales tax credit, paying US Bank Leasing more for my trade in, and they took it upon themselves to take my refund of {$610.00} and provide it to the dealership I traded my truck into. 

US Bank Leasing is a terrible company to do business with and as such, I will also be closing my checking and savings accounts with US Bank.

Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
TrueAccord Corporation Formal Demand for Damages, Removal of Derogatory Marks, and Cease Collection Efforts To Whom It May Concern : I am writing in regard to an alleged debt that your company has reported to the credit bureaus and is attempting to collect on behalf of XXXX XXXX XXXX After a thorough review of my records and applicable laws, I have determined that TrueAccord Corporation has violated several federal and Michigan state laws regarding debt collection practices. These violations entitle me to statutory and actual damages under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), and Michigan law. 

This letter serves as a formal demand for : Immediate removal of the alleged debt from all three credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX ). 
Cease all collection efforts and communications related to this alleged debt. 
Payment of {$20000.00} in damages for the violations outlined below. 

Legal Violations Violations of the FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ) Your actions have violated multiple provisions of the FDCPA, including but not limited to : False Representation of Debt ( 1692e ( 2 ) ) : Reporting or attempting to collect on a debt that I do not owe and that has not been properly validated. 
Failure to Validate Debt ( 1692g ( b ) ) : You continued collection efforts without validating the debt after my dispute. 
Threatening Actions You Can not Take ( 1692e ( 5 ) ) : Communicating or implying consequences such as lawsuits or wage garnishment without legal grounds.

Failure to Mark the Debt as Disputed ( 1692e ( 8 ) ) : Reporting the alleged debt to credit bureaus without marking it as disputed. 

Statutory Damages for FDCPA Violations : {$1000.00} per violation. 
FDCPA Total : {$4000.00}. 

Violations of the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) Reporting False Information ( 1681s-2 ( a ) ) : Reporting an alleged debt to credit bureaus without verifying its validity. 
Failure to Investigate Disputes ( 1681i ) : Failing to reasonably investigate my dispute with the credit bureaus. 

Statutory Damages for FCRA Violations : {$1000.00} per violation. 
FCRA Total : {$6000.00} ( assuming three bureaus, each with two violations ). 

Violations of Michigan State Law Fraudulent Misrepresentation ( MCL 750.218 ) : Attempting to collect a debt based on false or misleading representations. 
Harassment and Abuse ( MCL 750.411h ) : Engaging in repeated and unwarranted communications to intimidate or coerce payment. 
Identity Theft ( MCL 445.65 ) : Associating my personal information with an account that is not mine. 

Estimated Damages Under Michigan Law : {$8000.00}. 

Total Damages Based on the violations listed above, I am entitled to the following damages : FDCPA Violations : {$4000.00} FCRA Violations : {$6000.00} Michigan State Law : {$8000.00} Total Demand : {$20000.00} Demands To resolve this matter, I demand that TrueAccord Corporation : Cease all collection efforts related to this alleged debt. 
Remove all derogatory marks related to this debt from my credit reports with XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. 
Pay {$20000.00} in damages for the legal violations described above. 

Response Deadline If you fail to comply with these demands within 30 days of receipt of this letter, I will proceed with the following actions : File formal complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and Michigan Attorney Generals Office. 
Initiate a lawsuit in federal court to recover statutory and actual damages under the FDCPA, FCRA, and Michigan law. 

Notice of Cease and Desist Under 15 U.S.C. 1692c ( c ), I demand that you cease all communication with me regarding this debt unless it pertains to the requested validation or resolution of this matter. 

Send all correspondence and payment directly to the address listed above.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/2024, at approx. XXXX XXXX, a door-to-door salesman knocked on my front door selling XXXX XXXX XXXX. She provided no credentials that she actually worked for XXXX, nor that she was allowed to solicit door-to-door. After listening to the pitch for 5 minutes, the salesman ( XXXX XXXX ) let herself into the house without asking permission. At the time I was busy preparing to pick up my XXXX  child from school and take care of my XXXX child. My wife was, at the time, in XXXX on a XXXX trip. I thought it was inappropriate that the salesman let herself into my house, but I did not tell her to leave, as home security was something I had genuinely been thinking of. 

I had a XXXX doorbell at my front door, but I am not subscribed to have the feed stored. Thinking back, the salesman may have entered my house so that our conversation could not have been recorded. Once inside, the salesman continued her pitch. I repeatedly told her it would not be in the budget and that we could not afford the product. She then offered an extended, risk-free trial period on the product and services that would last 30 days. I asked what the cost would be of the product and services for the 30 days and she responded it would be just under {$1.00}. I then asked if, by agreeing to this extended trial period I would have any issues with any standard trial periods and she told me there would be no issues. I agreed to have the installation occur on the basis that we would have a 30 day, risk-free trial period. She said she would need a debit card to put on my account to pay the {$1.00} for the installation. I gave her the card number. 

She told me she would need to begin the account creation process and asked to take my picture with her XXXX. She said this was a part of the account creation process. Afterward she asked for my SSN which she also said was part of the account creation process. It was quickly becoming time for me to leave my house to pick up my child from school. She asked if she could join us and I agreed. In the car she asked if she could use my phone to complete the account creation process. I told her that would be fine as long as it was solely to finish creating an account. She took my phone and did, what I assumed, was what needed to happen to finish the account creation. She asked what my email address, phone number and street address were. Beyond this I was asked no more questions regarding account creation. 

When we arrived back home after I had picked up my child from school, she told me they would send somebody quickly to perform the security system installation. She told me the total cost of the installation and equipment would be approx {$3500.00}. I asked if there was anything I needed to sign before the installation had taken place and she told me I would only need to sign once the installer had arrived. I also asked XXXX who I should reach out to if I have any concerns or questions. She told me she would be my point-of-contact with XXXX and would answer any questions or concerns I had going forward. She gave me her phone number. I thanked her for her time and she left my house. 

Later that evening, an installer from XXXX arrived and performed the installation of all equipment in the XXXX XXXX XXXX which includes : XXXX external cameras ( over garage and in backyard ), smart thermostat, front door lock, smoke and CO monitor, door sensors, four window stickers, smart garage door opener, doorbell camera, and a yard sign. After the installation was completed, I was asked to sign the Schedule of Equipment and Services document, which I was told was just a verification that all products were installed at the time of the scheduled installation. I signed this document on the installers XXXX. The installer left my residence. 

After discussing the security system with my wife, we agreed that we no longer wanted it and would request an uninstall. On Monday, XX/XX/year> ( 12 days after the installation ) I tried sending a text message to XXXX asking to schedule an uninstall. When I received no response, I tried calling, which also got me no response. I then decided I would schedule the uninstall thru XXXX customer support. 

I called XXXX customer support and a rep answered and ultimately told me I could not cancel the contract unless I paid the total value of the products. I was told that their documentation on file said I had signed an agreement to a 3-day trial period. I had never signed this, nor been asked to sign this by the sales representative, nor any other XXXX representative. While speaking with the phone rep, I looked for an email of the documents that had my forged signatures. I saw an email from the same date as the installation with my forged signatures on the SYSTEM EQUIPMENT PURCHASE AND SERVICES AGREEMENT, XXXX CONSENT, and NOTICE OF CANCELLATION. I was never told that an email with any documents would be coming to me during my conversation with the door-to-door salesman, so I didnt think to check that email for anything at the time. Most importantly, I was never asked to sign these documents, nor was I asked if I verbally agreed to anything outlined in them. I asked to be put in contact with a manager or supervisor and my call was transferred to XXXX ( unsure of spelling ). XXXX reiterated that I would not be able to cancel the contract even though I had not signed the documents. I asked if XXXX had been in contact with the door-to-door salesman XXXX and they said they had not. I asked if they would try then and there. XXXX put me on hold for several minutes and came back to say he tried but that she did not answer. The call dropped abruptly and when I tried to call back they couldnt hear my voice. XXXX sent me an email recapping what we had talked about. 

After that call, I sent a hard copy of my intent to cancel, explaining how I should not have to pay for this equipment because : 1 ) I was within the 30-day trial period promised by the sales representative, XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX and 2 ) I did not sign the contract documents ; they were fraudulently signed by someone other than myself agreeing to terms and conditions that I did not agree with. The letter was delivered on XX/XX/year>. The only correspondence I have seen from XXXX since my phone call on XX/XX/XXXX, has been a form email, received on XX/XX/XXXX, reiterating that I do not qualify for cancellation of the contract. 

Around this same time, I received a credit card in the mail issued by Fortiva Bank. I didn't recognize the bank and did some more research and found that XXXX had opened an account and a line of credit in my name without my authorization. I also saw that my credit score had dropped XXXX points. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I called Fortiva Bank to open a dispute for the account being fraudulently opened in my name. I sent in pertinent documents, but have not heard about a resolution from them. I did receive confirmation that the dispute had been started.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My ex husband, XXXX and I obtained a mortgage loan with Wells Fargo in XX/XX/XXXX. The mortgage was in XXXX name alone however I was listed on the deed. In XXXX we did a loan modification due to a financial hardship and it the listed XXXX and I both as borrowers. In XX/XX/XXXX XXXX and I separated and he moved out of the home. I continued making the payments on time. XX/XX/XXXX I log into my Wells Fargo account to make my mortgage payment and something about forbearance immediately popped up. There was no wording about having to do a loan modification if I opted into the program. The information read like they would put payments at the end of the loan. I decided to do it with this understanding. I thought could payoff some other debts during that forbearance period. XX/XX/XXXX the forbearance ended and I had to start making the payments again. Then Wells Fargo called us saying we had to do a loan modification for the forbearance time period even if we continued to make the payment after the forbearance. I would have never opted into that program if it had said anything about a loan modification. Then we were told we were not eligible for the loan modification because XXXX no longer lived in the home. We were served with Foreclosure paperwork on Saturday XX/XX/XXXX. They will not allow me to do a loan modification by myself because they say I am not a borrower however the XXXX modification clearly list XXXX and I both as borrowers and we both signed as well and it is filed with the circuit clerks office as such on XX/XX/XXXX. The foreclosure paperwork includes interest, late fees and attorney fees as if I never did the forbearance ( cares act stated they are not allowed to charge these fees during that time of forbearance ) Now XX/XX/XXXX I was told by Wells Fargo if my ex husband and I did the quitclaim deed I would be able to do the loan modification in my name. I am now a successor of the loan but they still will not allow me to do the loan modification and are trying to move forward with foreclosure. Also on the foreclosure paperwork they list XXXX lien holders ( XXXX XXXX and XXXX  XXXX XXXX  which do not have a lien on my property. Please advise. 

Thank you! 
XXXX XXXX XXXX

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year> I booked three flights through XXXX for XXXX airline tickets for {$650.00} per ticket for a total of {$1900.00} from XXXX XXXX. The terms were that if the flights were canceled within XXXX hours they were fully refundable. Our plans changed, so I canceled the flights within the XXXX hour time period and received an email from XXXX ( attached ) on XX/XX/XXXX stating that the full amount of {$1900.00} would be refunded to my credit card. 

Over XXXX weeks passed and only {$320.00} had been credited to my account. First, I called XXXX XXXX, but they said XXXX had to tell them the amount that needed to be refunded, as I did not book the flights with XXXX directly but through XXXX, so there was nothing they could do unless they hard from XXXX. I called XXXX and they acknowledged that I canceled the flights within the XXXX hour time period and was entitled to the full refund of {$1900.00}. They said it could take up to XXXX months for the full amount to be refunded. They also said that it was possible the credit card company already had the funds but were withholding them. 

I called the credit card company, FNBO ( an XXXX credit card ) and they said XXXX had only sent the {$320.00}, so on XX/XX/XXXX I filed a dispute. There was some confusion, as the charges were listed on my credit card as XXXX separate charges of {$650.00} ( as opposed to the total amount paid of {$1900.00} stated in the XXXX email as the refund amount ). I was told I needed to file three separate disputes for each charge separately -- that is, three different disputes in the amount of {$650.00} each, but one of those had to take into account the difference between the amount already refunded ( {$320.00} ) and the remainder owed, which was {$330.00}. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, the first {$650.00} was credited to my account. On XXXX XXXX, the remaining {$330.00} was credited to my account for the second charge. However, on XXXX XXXX the final refund amount of {$650.00} was credited on to my account, but then reversed by FNBO and recharged to my account again for the final {$650.00}. 

I called the FNBO dispute department and they said XXXX 's policy was that flights were non-refundable. I explained that all three flights were booked at the same time and canceled at the same time ( within the XXXX hour time frame ), so why would XXXX flights be refundable and not the third? I sent FNBO disputes the email from XXXX that stated the full amount should be refunded ( {$1900.00} ) and explained the situation again as a new dispute, but FNBO said my cases were closed and there was nothing more they could do for me. 

So, they insisted I would NOT receive a refund for the final {$650.00}, and this amount remained on my card. I paid it off because I didn't want to pay interest on money I didn't actually owe and I waited, hoping XXXX would send the full refund to FNBO, they would see their mistake, and finally refund the full amount. However, by XX/XX/year> the money was still not refunded. Hence my complaint here, to the CFPB.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative: I have two loans with two different banks, XXXX XXXX  and BMO, both for recreational vehicles. Each loan is a fixed rate loan charged a daily interest rate. My monthly payments for each are distributed between principle and interest each month and I am completely aware that interest will be higher than the principle contributions. My issue is specifically on how they apply payments made in excess of what is owed as the minimum payment. Example ; fixed rate loan is 7.49 % with a monthly payment of {$560.00}. With exception of maybe 1 or 2 months, each month I have made payments in excess of that minimum amount. The idea was to have those applied to principle however that is not how they are applying payments. They are taking the excess monies and applying it to interest charges and then reducing the minimum payment amount for the following month by the overage amount that was applied to the interest charge. They are not applying this to principle. This practice seems incredibly unfair. They are taking my money which would allow for me to reduce the principle balance and instead applying to what I would XXXX future interest owned. They are applying it to their own interest income and changing me interest on a higher principle balance that I paid extra to reduce. After speaking to both companies, I was told that I have to actually go online, call, mail in or go into a branch to be sure that my additional payments are being allocated to principle. In fact, the BMO representative read me their internal policy or talking points and it said, excess payments were to be applied to principle but he assured me that that does not happen. If I am making my required minimum payment and then additional funds are received at the exact same time, why are they not applying those funds to benefit the consumer vs. themselves. This feels like a very unfair practice and almost deceptive. In order for clients to understand that what they intended to be principle contributions are not actually being applied, they would have to review their statements AND call the bank to understand why their payments are reflecting either a lower or no payment amount. I was told by the representative that even if I requested a reallocation of funds to be applied to principle vs. interest that in his experience, these are denied. He said it would be unsuccessful but did offer to submit it. This does not seem like a process that benefits the consumer at all and lines the pockets of the bank instead. I have two loans that this has happened to me on. Please review for unfair and deceptive practices.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

As a result of these violations, I am entitled to seek damage as specified under the FCRA. Therefore, I hereby demand compensation of {$1000.00} for each violation committed. This claim is made in accordance with 15 U.S.C. 1681n, which allows consumers to seek statutory damages for willful noncompliance with the FCRA. 

I expect a prompt and thorough response to this serious matter. Your lack of action concerning the legalities of your reporting will not be overlooked. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
