Product: Money transfer, virtual currency, or money service
Consumer complaint narrative:
Page XXXX of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) 1500 Pennsylvania Ave. NW Washington, DC XXXX
[WITHOUT PREJUDICE]
URGENCY: HIGH
IMPORTANCE: HIGH
This is to complain against U. S. Bank.
U. S. Bank account ending in: XXXX
I wish to practice my right as a customer of U. S. Bank to use your organisation's service, seeking a
formal, impartial investigation to amicably settle my dispute with U. S. Bank.
In order to clear up the myriad of letters and correspondences I have hitherto sent to U. S. Bank
respecting my complaint, I believe it will substantially strengthen both my case and your understanding,
by taking a deeper look at the happenings of my case, and analysing the relevant facts in an objective and
comprehensive fashion.
It is crucial to note that I have been manipulated, socially-engineered and coerced to engage these
fraudulent criminals. Much to my embarrassment, I recognise that I am the victim of an investment scam.
My complaint to the CFPB has arisen as I do not consider, by any stretch of the imagination, the conduct
of U. S. Bank to be commensurate with their legal role and responsibility to their customers. They sell a
service to look after their customers, protect their money and are a financial institution that maintains a
traditional relationship and way of working with its customers.
During the complaints process with U. S. Bank, I found their communication ineffective, which further
hides their conduct to management and diminishes the service offering to their clients. They are
struggling to adapt their business offering in the ever-changing world of IT development. The internet is
presenting a real problem which they choose to manage in a way which is not in line with rules and
regulations of CFPB as well as their own internal policy and procedures sold to their clients.
General Obligation:
Commencing on or about XXXX  2024, I fell victim to a multi-layered scam operations run by DML Markets under the domain m.dml-markets.cc which involved me making deposits for a total amount of XXXX  USD from my U. S. Bank account to fraudulent investment firm(s).
When determining whats reasonable and fair, we should focus on the issue of liability; common queries
include, but are not limited to, the following (i) whether U. S. Bank did not take notice of any rule, law, or
regulation, and/or possibly missed any material elements of the relevant bylaws or codes of conduct, that
may have prevented them from protecting my financial safety; (ii) whether by virtue of U. S. Banks
Page XXXX of XXXX
XX/XX/2024
custodianship over my funds or by its control over them, they owed a fiduciary duty to the me and if so,
whether that duty was breached; (iii) whether U. S. Bank promoted the transaction(s) in question despite
being aware of the nature of the transaction(s) in question (iv) whether U. S. Bank was in compliance
with its own policies and procedures; (v) whether U. S. Bank owed duties to myself, what the scope of
those duties was, and whether U. S. Bank did not uphold those duties; (vi) whether U. S. Banks conduct
was unfair; and (vii) whether U. S. Bank has within its power the ability to, and should, compensate me
for the harm that has befallen me.
Upon identification of such unusual or suspicious activity, it is crucial that the relevant staff member
adequately describe the factors making an activity or transaction suspicious, thoroughly depict the extent
and nature of this activity and properly communicate to the customer that such activity meets the relevant
criteria of fraud.
In providing its services to a customer, a financial institution is required by law to exercise the care and
skill of a diligent, prudent banker. In this case, this means that the payment service provider should not
turn a blind eye to known facts pointing to a real possibility that their customer is being scammed. In
other words, U. S. Bank must have had special knowledge of what was occurring or been alerted to a real
possibility of fraud taking place. The financial institution must have known or reasonably ought to have
known that I was dealing with a scammer.
Granted, there is room for diversity of view insofar as reasonableness is concerned. Indeed, there is a
sense in which the standard of care of the reasonable person involves in its application a subjective
element.
However, it must be remembered that the correct test is always reasonable care in all circumstances, not
average care. The fact that most people behave in a certain way may be good evidence that the conduct is
reasonable, but this is not necessarily the case. Although reasonableness is a very fluid concept, all of
the evidence suggests that U. S. Bank did not foresee the fraud and disregarded even the most obvious
dangers in this respect.
Situations do tend to repeat themselves and it is advisable to examine previous outcomes to see how the
standard of the reasonable person should be applied, and that lessons can be learnt from the errors of the
past.
U. S. Banks Position:
OnXX/XX/2024 U. S. Bank wrote in a letter We regret any frustration or inconvenience this matter
may have caused you. We understand that being the victim of a scam can be confusing, time consuming,
and inconvenient.
Upon receiving your request for assistance, our records confirm two claims were opened with our Wire
Department on XXXX XXXX which debited your account ending XXXX  on XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX in the amounts
of XXXX and XXXX  A request was sent to the beneficiary bank for recall of these funds.
Please know, the receiving institution is not obligated to return these funds or respond to our request. The
elapsed time from the time of the transfers to the time of the claim submission limits the chances of
recalling the funds. We recommend you also continue working directly with your local law enforcement
officials to attempt to recover your money from the beneficiary of this payment.
Page XXXX of XXXX
XX/XX/2024Refuting U. S. Banks arguments from a purely logical perspective:
U. S. Banks position is that the features of the situation at hand do not generate a genuine obligation to
protect innocent and helpless victims; they are essentially arguing that common-sense-based approaches
are doomed to fail, leaving their exclusively technical account of the subject matter as the only
meaningful choice. For reasons which are unclear, this extremely serious situation barely gets the
attention it deserves even though ample evidence has been offered in support of this complaint.
In U. S. Banks view, it is implied that we should not home in (and consequently rely) on unwritten laws,
practicality, good judgement, reasonableness, sharpness, sensibleness, past outcomes, and insight, when
taking appropriate precautions. To underscore, once again, such views are at odds with common sense
and are wildly irresponsible.
Imagine a view according to which the one and only thing that can make U. S. Bank morally obligated to
do something is having it written down somewhere. Pursuant to this view, if U. S. Bank encounter the
suffering of totally naive victims, they are only obligated to intervene in or remedy the situation, to the
degree required by written material. This is unbecoming for a reputable establishment such as U. S. Bank.
I have reviewed the material hereto sent by U. S. Bank carefully, and it unfortunately provides no
response to my fundamental argument concerning the degree of care. Given its size, influence, and the
resources at its disposal, this establishment clearly had a far greater capacity than an individual such as
myself had, to determine the level and likelihood of risk that a client such as myself is subjected to and
had a duty to intervene as they now do to query in particular out-of-pattern transactions of this kind.
It is perfectly obvious that U. S. Bank, inadvertently, employs a subtle approach in addressing some of the
key questions in a manner which neither provides me with adequate support nor protects anything other
than its own interests.
It is U. S. Bank here, who has the burden of proof, to show that it has exercised the duty of care, that is to
say, that U. S. Bank adhered to a standard of reasonable care in relation to the matter at issue given its
extensive experience compared to mine. It is U. S. Bank that claims that the damages which I have
suffered in connection to this matter have not been reasonably foreseeable, and that my proposed degree
of care is not, and has not been, commensurate with U. S. Banks capacity, experience, expertise, or scope
of services in any way. To reemphasize, U. S. Banks indisputable overriding purpose is by no means to
purely execute transactions in a blind and blank fashion, but rather to strike a balance between executing
those transactions and capitalising on its undeniably vast capabilities to protect consumers thereby
enhancing market integrity.
Apropos of the fluidity of the concept of reasonableness, all U. S. Bank has done in this regard is set up a
dichotomy of having or not having the legal obligation under consideration, however, that does not go
one-inch toward explaining why various regulatory authorities, has maintained that financial institutions
can, and should, protect consumers using their systems, advanced technologies, and rich experience.
U. S. Bank is obliged to take some action if it is sufficiently aware of a real possibility that a fraud may
be being perpetuated. If you don't question its customers instructions or raise the possibility of a scam
with the customer in these circumstances, it may be liable if the red flags indicate the customer is:
 particularly vulnerable, or
Page XXXX of XXXX  XX/XX/2024
 if the possibility of fraud was serious or real, not just suspected.
There are some recommendations to organisations for protecting customers from financial harm that
might occur as a result of fraud or financial abuse; and gives guidance on how to recognise customers
who might be at risk, how to assess the potential risks to the individual and how to take the necessary
actions to prevent or minimise financial harm.
These recommendations are established as a general principle, the organisation should deliver a
service that:
XXXX) Takes a proactive approach to minimising risks, impact and incidences of financial harm and it
sets out systems and tools for the prevention and detection of fraud and financial abuse. As a general
point, it says organisations should ensure that all systems are developed using technologies and
methodologies that are effective in the prevention of fraud and financial abuse, through authorised
and unauthorised payments, thereby minimising the risk of financial harm to customers. As regards to
the detection of fraud and financial abuse, it says the organisation:
A) should have measures in place across all payment channels and products to detect suspicious
transactions or activities that might indicate fraud or financial abuse. It then lists the following
examples of suspicious activity on customer accounts:
a. multiple cheque books;
b. sudden increased spending;
c. transfers to other accounts;
d. multiple password attempts;
e. logins from new devices, multiple geographical locations;
f. sudden changes to the operation of the account; Unusual transactions are
transactions whose amount, characteristics and frequency bear no relation to the
economic activity of the customer, exceed normal market parameters or have no
apparent legal justification.
g. a withdrawal or payment for a large amount;
h. a payment or series of payments to a new payee;
i. financial activity that matches a known method of fraud or financial abuse.
B) organisations should have a process in place to ensure that staff make contact with the
customer to verify the financial activity, challenge its authenticity, explain the nature of the
suspected or detected fraud and discuss an appropriate plan of action.
U. S. Bank are yet to show, or otherwise provide me with, a compelling argument that their wide-ranging
experience and wealth of specialist knowledge in detecting transactional anomalies were not sufficient to
avert the fraud at issue. By contrast, I have provided a multitude of sound and powerful reasons by which
Page XXXX of XXXX
XX/XX/2024requiring their involvement has not only been pressingly relevant but also eminently reasonable and well-
justified.
Rather than empathising with and undertaking substantial efforts to convey their knowledge of the
existence of such regulations abroad and thereafter use it to protect and proactively relieve the plight of
consumers who have been cheated out of their money and whose role in society is properly fulfilled,
positively contributing to local economic growth, development and sustainability  U. S. Bank adopts a
rather insouciant attitude toward my financial predicament portrayed herein.
I am deeply convinced that the disastrous results that I have previously elaborated upon will continue to
ensue if no responsibility is adopted by U. S. Bank in relation to this matter. I have also thoroughly
detailed why they cannot simply dismiss this problem by strictly adhering to legal technicalities which,
after careful reflection, struck me as being nothing more than self-interest. Indeed, it seems to me utterly
unfair to disregard fragile, sensitive, and vulnerable consumers who are afflicted by such allegedly
malevolent acts, thereby keeping an unjust status-quo that is corrupting our society at its core.
Conclusion:
Based on my analysis, and as confirmed by various authorities concerned with such matters, there is
abundant evidence that forward-thinking financial institutions ought to take reasonable steps to forestall
fraud, or at least mitigate its risk by using an effective risk management system, demonstrating their
undisputed ability to responsibly and pre-emptively respond to questionable transactions in the digital
arena. The use of such systems, largely based on newly adopted technologies aimed at effectively
navigating the evolving threat landscape, is only one of a number of possible endeavours undertaken in
this connection, alongside the application of past knowledge and experience related to popular fraudulent
practices.
Astonishingly, I am pondering how it is that, despite being shown that U. S. Banks business conduct was
insufficient insofar as background checks are concerned, they keep refuting their indisputable role and
responsibility in connection with the matter herein discussed. The points that I have hitherto made are too
crucial to be taken lightly. U. S. Banks non-observance of the fundamental principles of justice  that is,
to completely overlook and not even remotely try to mitigate the suffering of vulnerable consumers is
inexcusable given the size of the establishment and the vast resources at its disposal as the direct result of
the patronage of clients like myself.
If it was, indeed, solely my responsibility, we must then believe at least one of the following clauses: a)
financial institutions have absolutely no role whatsoever in preventing and detecting fraud, b) the fraud in
question was not reasonably foreseeable, or c) the transactions in question were not sufficiently alarming.
It is extremely unfortunate that U. S. Bank pushes quite hard for me to believe all three of these things
despite evidence to the contrary.
In summary, I respectively ask your organisation to consider my points, given your personal and
companywide obligation to provide a fair and reasonable investigation into the complaint.
I look forward to your input and would gladly cooperate to reach a fair and reasonable outcome.
Thank you.

usbankXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX CA XXXX  Re: Account ending in XXXX
Dear XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX:
The Office of the President received your request for assistance. We appreciate the opportunity to respond to your
c o n c e r n s .
We regret any frustration or inconvenience this matter may have caused you. We understand that being the victim of a
scam can be confusing, time consuming, and inconvenient.
Upon receiving your request for assistance, our records confirm two claims were opened with our Wire Department on
XXXX XXXX  which debited your account ending XXXX on XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in the amounts of XXXX XXXX XXXX. A
request was sent to the beneficiary bank for recall of these funds.
Please know, the receiving institution is not obligated to return these funds or respond to our request. The elapsed time
from the time of the transfers to the time of the claim submission limits the chances of recalling the funds. We
recommend you also continue working directly with your local law enforcement officials to attempt to recover your
money from the beneficiary of this payment.
Please refer to the section of the Your Deposit Account Agreement (Agreement) titled Funds Transfers, which states, "A
wire transfer is irrevocable once payment has been transmitted to the beneficiary's bank. At your request, we may
request that the beneficiary's bank return funds previously transferred. However, you acknowledge that the beneficiary's
bank is under no obligation to comply with this request." The most current copy of the Agreement is available on
usbank.com or at your local U.S. Bank branch. The Agreement is also included with the documentation provided when a
new account is opened.
Our customers are generally protected from liability for unauthorized transactions or fraud. Any transactions you initiate
are considered authorized by you. Also, if you send funds to someone for products or services, and they fail to deliver the
desired service, it becomes a civil matter and unfortunately falls outside of our ability to recover those funds. We
recommend you continue to work with the recipient of the funds to request a refund. You may also consider working with
your local law enforcement officials to attempt to recover your money from the beneficiary of this payment.
In your correspondence you enclosed a statement and mention four additional fraudulent transfers on your account
ending XXXX  in the amounts oXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Please note, we were unable to locate any claims on
the transactions mentioned above. If there are transactions you believe should be disputed, please contact our Fraud
Dispute Intake team at XXXX to file a claim, where representatives are available to assist you XXXX  hours a day,
seven days a week (we accept relay calls).
Additionally, in your correspondence you also expressed concern regarding our alleged failure to prevent the above
transactions from occurring. A review of the wire interaction confirmed the branch representative asked appropriate
verification questions and determined you had previously sent similar wires.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have a " XXXX  '' savings account under my name at Wells Fargo for my child. My child was a victim of XXXX  wherein fraudsters contacted him and threatened him and demanded money. My child made several XXXX XXXX payments through the Wells Fargo banking application on his phone to the scammers, as follows : XXXX ) XX/XX/year> in the amount of {$550.00} via XXXX XXXX. 
XXXX ) XX/XX/year> in the amount of {$50.00} via XXXX XXXX. 
XXXX ) XX/XX/year> in the amount of {$250.00} via XXXX. 
XXXX ) XX/XX/year> in the amount of {$250.00} via XXXX. 
XXXX ) XX/XX/year> in the amount of {$500.00} via XXXX- which Wells Fargo declined and did not complete the transaction because there was suspicious activity/possible fraud. 

On XX/XX/year> my XXXX  alerted me to the situation and I visited my neighborhood branch on XX/XX/year>. I worked with the branch XXXX to submit disputes for the XXXX ( XXXX ) {$250.00} payments made via XXXX on XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year>, respectively. The branch XXXX also submitted a claim on the {$500.00} payment made via XXXX on XX/XX/year> because he said he wanted to do that just to be on the safe side. I was given a printed summary of my visit to the branch, with the following reference/case numbers : XXXX ) Ref # XXXX in regard to the {$500.00} payment on XX/XX/year> via XXXX. 
XXXX ) Ref # XXXX in regard to the {$250.00} payment on XX/XX/year> via XXXX. 
XXXX ) Ref # XXXX in regard to the {$250.00} payment on XX/XX/year> via XXXX. 

Wells Fargo responded to the XXXX claims approximately XXXX weeks later ( Wells Fargo XXXX XXXX me that they would respond within XXXX business days. There were never provisional credits made for the XXXX {$250.00} payments ). This is a violation of Regulation XXXX due to no provisional credit being issued by the bank and the time to resolve the claim was longer than 30 days ( even though the letters I eventually received were dated XX/XX/year> - the same day I visited the branch to make the dispute claims ). 

The results of the banks research as stated in those letters is outlined below : XXXX ) Ref # XXXX in regard to the {$500.00} stated that there was no error as Wells Fargo had not completed the transaction and money had never been debited from my account. I have no issue with that but will point out that this transaction was initiated on XX/XX/year> ( same day as a {$250.00} payment was sent, also via XXXX and XXXX days prior to the XXXX XXXX XXXX payments totaling {$600.00} were initiated ). Wells Fargo detected suspicious activity and shut down the transaction. 
XXXX ) Both claims on Ref # XXXX and Ref # XXXX regarding the XXXX {$250.00} XXXX payments on XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year>, respectively, were denied. Wells Fargo stated that no error had occurred. 

The reason that there were no claims submitted by myself and the branch XXXX regarding the XXXX XXXX payments totaling {$600.00} is because my XXXX  had called Wells Fargo on XX/XX/year> and requested to cancel those payments and was informed that the cancellations were successful. Additionally, the bank account showed that the payments were pended and did not go through ; therefore, the branch XXXX advised that it was not necessary to submit claims for those XXXX cancelled payments. What I believe actually happened is that the representative that my child spoke with at Wells Fargo on the night of XX/XX/year> advised that the bank would provide provisional credits for the {$50.00} and {$550.00} XXXX XXXX payments while the bank researched the inquiry. I believed that the payments were voided based on my childs conversation with the bank and a letter I received weeks later stating that the account had been provisionally credited in the amount of {$600.00}. There was a reference number on that letter : XXXX. 

After receiving the XXXX denial letters, I visited the same branch on XX/XX/year> to appeal the decisions and have the cases for the XXXX {$250.00} payments via XXXX escalated to the banks XXXX office as no one had ever contacted me to obtain the police report number and FBI report I filed with their XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX division. I was given a new reference number for the escalated case : XXXX and the branch XXXX scanned all of the additional documentation with the full FBI report into the Wells Fargo system. 

I received several emails from Wells Fargo after XX/XX/year>, and each time it stated that more time was needed to research my case. These emails originated from Wells Fargos executive office, therefore I believed that these emails were in regard to the XXXX office escalated case number XXXX for the XXXX {$250.00} XXXX payments. 

Finally, on XX/XX/year>, I received another email from Wells Fargos executive office stating that the claim for the XXXX Apple Cash payments ( {$600.00} together ) was finally resolved and that Wells Fargo concluded through its research that no processing error occurred and that the bank would deduct the provisional credit in the amount of {$600.00} from my account on XX/XX/year>. This email that I received on XX/XX/year> was received 92 days after the call my child placed regarding these transactions on XX/XX/year>. That is a violation of Regulation XXXX due to the time it took to research the case. 

I have not yet heard back from Wells Fargo about the appeal on the XXXX {$250.00} XXXX payments. I am placing this complaint in part to explain that Wells Fargo is not putting appropriate protections on its minor accounts. The bank grants access to minors to its online app and offers XXXX  the ability to make payments from that app. The bank is an owner of XXXX and there are well-documented cases and investigations by the CFPB into XXXX high number of claims that consumers make regarding XXXX, which the banks ( not just Wells Fargo XXXX but XXXX, XXXX well ) summarily denyXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXs a major problem in this country. There are no protections in place at Wells Fargo and other banks to prevent the exact situation that I went through from happening to more and more children each and every day. 

Wells Fargo knew very well that the transactions on my childs minor account were suspicious and yet the payments were allowed to go through. In fact, the bank stopped a XXXX payment that my child initiated on XX/XX/year> because it detected the fraudulent and/or suspicious activity. Then, XXXX full days later, it allowed XXXX XXXX XXXX payments to go through, even though there were the same clear signs of suspicious activity. I was notified of nothing. Obviously when the FBI opens a case in the XXXX and XXXX XXXX unit, and there is ample information with names, email addresses, phone numbers, and screenshots from the scammers all also provided to Wells Fargo there is merit to the argument that these are cases of fraud and scams.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am experiencing issues with my mortgage servicer, RoundPoint Mortgage Servicing LLC, regarding the removal of escrow and Private Mortgage Insurance ( PMI ) from my mortgage account. Despite fulfilling all specified requirements, including maintaining a Loan-to-Value ( LTV ) ratio well below the required 80 %, RoundPoint Mortgage has repeatedly added new conditions, delayed the process, and provided conflicting information, preventing the removal of both PMI and escrow. 

Complaint Details : Initial Request and Requirements Fulfilled : On XX/XX/year>, I requested to have the escrow removed from my mortgage. RoundPoint acknowledged receipt of my request on XX/XX/XXXX at XXXXXXXX XXXX. and informed me that PMI would need to be removed first to proceed. 
I submitted a request to remove PMI and provided all necessary documentation, including a Broker Price Opinion ( BPO ) that confirmed my LTV is well below the 80 % threshold required for PMI removal. The BPO was completed and returned to RoundPoint on XX/XX/year>, as confirmed by the broker who submitted it. 
Repeated Delays and Added Stipulations : Despite meeting the required conditions, RoundPoint has repeatedly delayed the process by introducing new, uncommunicated stipulations. Most recently, on XX/XX/year>, RoundPoint added a requirement that PMI and escrow can not be removed because the property is located in a FEMA-designated disaster area. 
This FEMA-related stipulation was never disclosed in prior communications or outlined in my mortgage documents. Each time I fulfill a requirement, RoundPoint imposes additional stipulations, effectively preventing the timely removal of PMI and escrow. This pattern of continually moving the goalposts appears to be a tactic to maintain escrow and PMI, creating undue frustration and financial burden. 
Escrow Payment Increase Without Adjustment : My monthly mortgage payment increased from {$3600.00} to {$4300.00} due to a significant rise in my propertys assessed value. If the property value had not increased, this payment adjustment would not have occurred. Despite this, my Homestead Credit has not been applied, and my escrow payments have only increased with no reduction or adjustment, contrary to CFPB Regulation 1024.17, which governs escrow maintenance and adjustments. 
Similar Complaints from Other Customers : Through research, I found multiple similar complaints from other RoundPoint Mortgage customers, who have faced similar delays and additional requirements when attempting to remove PMI and escrow. These practices appear to be systemic and designed to prevent timely removal of these obligations. 
Request for Resolution : I am seeking the CFPBs assistance to : Ensure RoundPoint Mortgage complies with federal regulations and my mortgage agreement, particularly regarding escrow adjustments and the removal of PMI. 
Obtain immediate removal of PMI and escrow based on my LTV compliance and the fulfillment of all disclosed requirements. 
Investigate RoundPoint Mortgages practices concerning delays, additional stipulations, and FEMA-related restrictions that were not previously disclosed, to ensure fair treatment of all customers. 
Supporting Documentation : Copies of all communication with RoundPoint Mortgage regarding PMI and escrow removal. 
BPO verifying my LTV is below 80 %. 
Documentation of payment increase due to property value reassessment.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/year>, I attempted to log in to the Wells Fargo website from my laptop and was unable to do so. I received a message for a security code to be entered with code from my mobile device. I entered the code and was still unable to get access to my online banking. I then attempted to login on my phone and was able to access my accounts and noticed a large amount of money was missing from my business account. I then called the fraud department for Wells Fargo to report that I did not authorize the " pending '' wire transfer of {$18000.00} from my account ( call occurred 5 minutes after the incident ). The representative proceeded to work on my claim request and start a recall. I told him I did not know the intended receiver of the wire transfer and was unaware that the wire was being sent to XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. I received a call on Tuesday, XX/XX/year>, at XXXX PM, stating that my claim was being processed and if I had any questions or concerns or would like to add any additional information to the claim, to call. I returned this call Tuesday, XX/XX/year>, at XXXX PM, and was told my claim had been denied without opportunity to provide any additional documentation. During the follow up call at XXXX PM, the Wells Fargo representative did say the claim was denied due to the wire transfer being initiated from a known mobile device, but none of that information is mentioned in the denial letter that I received or documentation to show how this determination was made. I have not been able to speak with or have received a return call from anyone that was involved with the investigation of my fraud claim. There is only the one missed follow up call from Wells Fargo on Tuesday, XX/XX/year>, at XXXX PM. I have only spoken with representatives that have answered my calls and made notes to send over for review. There also has been on documentation or information provided to show investigation of the inconsistency in the transaction based on the other activities of my account. This fraudulent wire transfer has been reported to the police for further investigation. On Tuesday, XX/XX/year>, I visited my neighborhood Wells Fargo branch with supporting documentation including the case number for my police report and submitted a appeal to my initial claim. On XX/XX/year>, I received an email that my appeal was also denied with no further information to support this decision. I am now awaiting findings from the police investigation to see if I can get my funds returned.

Consumer complaint narrative:
This is my response to your letter I received on XX/XX/XXXX, regarding Fraud Denied Reference Number DT XXXX ( attached file : 1. XXXX  ). 

I am a victim of identity theft and have been attempting for more than the past two years to remove fraudulent accounts from my credit reports. According to 15 U.S.C. 1681i, PROCOLLECT , INC is obligated to investigate disputes within 30 days, but I have not received any update or resolution. This delay constitutes a violation of my rights. Furthermore, under 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( a ) and 1681b, a consumer report can not be shared without my written consent unless exceptions apply. I request confirmation that my consent was obtained for any recent disclosures of my credit report. As part of my efforts to resolve this matter, I have filed a formal complaint with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) under report number XXXX and expect PROCOLLECT , INC to cooperate with the FTC in addressing these concerns. I further request that erroneous information be corrected or removed immediately. Please provide a detailed written response outlining the steps taken to resolve these issues and ensure compliance with the FCRA. Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXXXXXX XX/XX/year> XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

Subject : Response to XXXXnadequate Validation and Notice of Intent to Proceed with Arbitration Account Number : XXXX Dear Kikoff Customer Support, I am writing in response to your email regarding my dispute of inaccurate information reported to credit bureaus and the accompanying documents you provided. After reviewing your response, I have determined that your investigation and validation are insufficient to meet the requirements under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and other applicable consumer protection laws. 
Issues with Kikoffs Response and Documentation Failure to Provide Proper Validation : The payment history document provided does not substantiate the accuracy of the information you reported. A proper validation must include : Specific dates payments were due and made. 
Evidence that the information reported was accurate and not misleading. 
The document fails to meet this standard, making the reported information unverifiable and inaccurate. 
Lack of Adequate Notification : Your email references email reminders, but there is no evidence provided to confirm that these were received or acknowledged. Sole reliance on email, which could be filtered or overlooked, does not meet the standard for proper notification under the FCRA. 
Misrepresentation of Consumer Rights : Your statement that historical activity remains with the bureaus and can not be removed misrepresents my rights under the FCRA. Any inaccurate or unverifiable information must be corrected or removed, regardless of its status as historical. 
Inadequate Investigation : Your investigation appears to rely solely on internal records without conducting a reasonable and thorough review, as required under the FCRA. This does not address the specifics of my dispute or provide evidence of a proper validation process. 
Failure to Apply Grace Periods : Your response mentions a 30-day grace period, but there is no evidence showing this was consistently applied before reporting any alleged delinquencies.

Notice of Intent to Proceed with Arbitration Given Kikoff , Inc.s failure to resolve this matter and its continued violations of my consumer rights, I have no choice but to pursue arbitration as outlined in the Kikoff Credit Account Agreement. A Notice of Dispute will be sent to your legal address : HERE IS THE TRACKING NUMBER FOR CERTIFIED MAIL ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) Kikoff Lending , LLC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX This notice will detail the violations and the relief I am seeking. Arbitration will impose significant costs on your company, including legal fees, arbitration fees, and potential damages awarded. 
I also want to let you know that I have all the evidence I need to substantiate the violations committed by Kikoff Lending against me. This includes documentation of your failure to validate, inadequate notifications, and inaccuracies in your reporting. 
Thank you for your time. I will also be filing formal complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) and any applicable regulatory bodies overseeing Kikoff Lending , Inc., to address your continued violations of consumer protection laws. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
" I am filing this complaint against XXXX XXXX XXXX for multiple violations of federal debt collection laws, specifically the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) and the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 

Failure to Validate the Debt : I made multiple formal requests for debt validation under 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( b ). XXXX failed to provide proper validation, such as a copy of the original signed contract or proof of the current owner 's right to collect the debt. Instead, they provided insufficient documentation, such as account summaries and transaction histories, which do not meet the legal standard for debt validation. 

Improper Transfer of Alleged Debt : After my validation requests, Resurgent transferred or sold the alleged debt to third parties ( Credit Control LLC and XXXX XXXX XXXX ). I subsequently requested validation from these parties and informed XXXX that such actions violated the FDCPA 's prohibition against collection activities until the debt is validated. 

Reinitiating Collection Activities : After the accounts were transferred to third parties and I flagged the violations, XXXX resumed attempts to collect the debt directly, without resolving the prior validation issues. This constitutes an additional violation of 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( b ), which prohibits any further collection efforts until the requested validation is provided. 

Reporting of Unvalidated Debt to Credit Bureaus : XXXX continues to report these alleged debts to credit reporting agencies despite failing to validate the debts. This violates XXXX U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) and 1681s-2 ( b ) of the FCRA, which require that all reported information must be accurate and verifiable.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Credit inquiries on your report that you don't recognize
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I mailed a dispute and request to XXXX requesting certification under FCRA section 604 ( a ) ( 2 ) as instructed by me that I gave permission to disseminate my credit report. I am writing to formally file a complaint against XXXX regarding multiple unauthorized disclosures of my credit report to creditors included in my XXXX  XXXX Bankruptcy proceedings, as well as other violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). These unauthorized actions have caused significant harm to my credit and have been done without my consent or any permissible purpose. 

Background and Unauthorized Credit Report Disclosures : In XXXX, I filed for XXXX  XXXX Bankruptcy, and as part of that process, certain accounts were discharged, including those with XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Account Ending # XXXX ), XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Ending # XXXX ), and XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX However, XXXX continued to disseminate my credit report to these and other creditors despite the discharge of these debts. 

Select Portfolio Servicing ( Account Ending # XXXX ) : This account was included in my XXXX  XXXX Bankruptcy and discharged in XXXX. Despite this, XXXX continued to report a balance on this account for XXXX months, from XXXX through XXXX, and shared my credit report with XXXX XXXX XXXX without any permissible purpose. 

XXXX XXXX ( Account Ending # XXXX ) : Similarly, this account was included in the bankruptcy, but XXXX continued to report it as a charge-off, which is inaccurate and misleading. This reporting is contrary to the discharge of the debt, and XXXX had no legal basis for continuing to share this information with creditors. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXX provided my credit report to XXXX XXXX XXXX on several occasions, including : XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX However, XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent me a letter dated XX/XX/XXXX, confirming that they have not placed any credit inquiries on my report. I am submitting this correspondence as evidence that these credit inquiries were unauthorized. 

Fifth Third Bank : This account was also included in my XXXX XXXX Bankruptcy, and XXXX provided my credit report to XXXX XXXX XXXX on multiple occasions : XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Since this debt was discharged, these actions constitute unauthorized access to my credit report and violations of the FCRA. 

Request for Compensation and Remediation : These unauthorized disclosures have caused significant damage to my credit, and I am requesting the following remedies : Statutory Damages : I am requesting {$38000.00} in statutory damages under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) for these violations, which I understand are actionable under Section 1681n of the FCRA, which allows for recovery of actual or statutory damages up to {$1000.00} per violation. 

In addition to the damages for unauthorized access to my credit report, I am also entitled to statutory damages for willful noncompliance by XXXX under Section 1681n of the FCRA. 

Inquiries Removal : I am requesting that all unauthorized credit inquiries be deleted from my credit report, including those made by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, and XXXX XXXX XXXX  , as they were not made with a permissible purpose under Section 604 ( a ) ( 2 ) of the FCRA. 

Cease Unauthorized Access : I request that XXXX cease disclosing my credit report to these creditors and any other unauthorized parties. Any future disclosures should only occur with written consent from me, in accordance with the requirements of the FCRA. 

Legal Support and Case Law : The actions of XXXX in disseminating my credit report without a permissible purpose and continuing to report inaccurate information violate the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. ), specifically Sections 604 and 1681n. These statutory violations have been addressed in case law within the XXXX XXXX and across XXXX XXXX, which have consistently held that consumers are entitled to damages for improper reporting and disclosure. 

FCRA Section 604 ( a ) ( 2 ) limits who can access a consumers credit report to those with a permissible purpose. 
FCRA Section 1681n provides for statutory damages of up to {$1000.00} per violation for willful noncompliance.

Case law supports that reporting of discharged debts post-bankruptcy or the unauthorized access to consumer credit reports is an actionable violation under the FCRA. 
I am attaching all relevant documentation, including my XXXX XXXX Discharge Order, correspondence from XXXX XXXX XXXX, and any other evidence supporting my claim. 

Conclusion : I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) investigate these actions and assist in securing the requested {$38000.00} in statutory damages for these violations, as well as require XXXX to remove the unauthorized inquiries from my credit report and cease further unauthorized disclosures. My consumer report has had a freeze for well over XXXX  months, and these unauthorized inquiries are unlawful and in violation of my rights. XXXX has a history of requesting copies of an individual 's id and social security when it was included in the original dispute as a stalling tactic. Exhibits of correspondence attached, dated XX/XX/XXXX. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Please confirm receipt of this complaint and keep me informed of any developments. Should you need any further information contact me. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Consumer Report showing unauthorized inquiries XXXX  XXXX Discharge Order Correspondence from XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Additional Exhibits as Relevant

Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted a debt validation request to Eastern and also requested the company to cease and desist, explicitly requesting no further communication concerning this debt. Despite these actions, Eastern has reported this account to my consumer credit report. 

these actions are in direct violation of the FDCPA, which prohibits debt collectors from continuing to collect on disputed debt without proper validation. Reporting the account to credit bureaus while its under dispute also violates my rights under the FCRA. 

I have attempted to resolve this matter, I requested Eastern to send me specific information to validate the alleged debt. instead they only sent me a bill of the debt ; Eastern needs to send me the original contract or agreement that outlines the terms of the debt, including the amount owed and the date it originated. I need a complete history of payments made toward the debt, including dates, amounts, and how those payments were applied. also the name of any other entities that may have owned or serviced the debt prior to collection.

I need documentation that proves the collection agency has the legal right to collect on the debt, including any assignment or transfer of the debt.

I need details on when the debt was reported to credit bureaus, including information on how it is impacting my credit report. 

I have attempted to resolve this matter directly with the collection agency, but they have ignored my requests and continued their collection efforts. 

I am requesting that the CFPB investigate this matter and take appropriate action against EASTERN to ensure compliance with federal consumer protection laws

Sub-issue: Loan sold or transferred to another company
Consumer complaint narrative:
This complaint is in reference to the property located at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, VA XXXX. XXXX XXXX owned this property for decades. The home was given to her. She grew up in the house. Many members of my family grew up in this house. It is our family home for over 4 generations. After XXXX XXXXs husband passed ( XXXX XXXX XXXX deceased for nearly 10 years ), she was the only owner on title until her passing in XXXX. Following her death, the property was put into a trust. That particular trust had XXXX XXXX, a minor child, listed as the primary beneficiary of the property mentioned above ( I, XXXX XXXX, am the trustee of XXXX XXXX 's property ). Since XXXX, the company M & T Bank confirmed with us that they were sending mortgage statements in the name of the deceased, XXXX XXXX XXXX. After years of negligence, addressing the mortgage to the incorrect party ( not even the current owner, XXXX XXXX, M & T bank decided to place this mortgage account with the company XXXX XXXX to commence with collections efforts and foreclosure proceedings. The foreclosure, also confirmed by XXXX from M & T bank ( on a recorded call from Tuesday, XX/XX/XXXX around the time XXXX EST ), commenced in XX/XX/XXXX. We were made aware of this a few weeks ago, when I received a letter in the mail from XXXX XXXX saying the property would be auctioned on XX/XX/XXXX. It was also stated and confirmed by the representative from M & T mentioned above, that mail was going to the address in the name of the incorrect party for years. The mail was being sent to the property in the name of the deceased, XXXX XXXX XXXX, who was not an owner of the property after his passing. The title was passed to XXXX solely via right of survivorship. The current residents had no reason to open any mail addressed to XXXX XXXX XXXX. Furthermore, XXXX XXXX who did live at the property until attending college this fall ( turning XXXX in XXXX ), had no knowledge of any financial responsibility to M & T Bank. Again, he was a minor until XXXX of this year. I received no notification of any late payments via mortgage statements or otherwise as the trustee of this property belonging to XXXX. 

Long story short, M & T Bank never properly advised or disclosed to the correct/responsible parties that the home was behind on payments. They began foreclosure proceedings before the beneficiary of the trust was legally of age to receive such documentation, and myself as the trustee was never notified until I received a letter in the mail referencing an auction next month for the property. I believe this is a violation of our rights. It feels unfair to sell our family home from under us after years of negligence while addressing incorrect parties via mail only about any past due balances. They couldn't address the right parties then, but when it came time to auction the house, they got in contact with us just fine. It feels like M & T Bank is stealing from us and forcing us to incur fees for their inner-workings in their foreclosure process. I believe this also to be a UDAAP violation ( if it applies to mortgages ), and it is certainly a Reg Z/TILA violation as well. I believe this could also be a deeper issue relating to HMDA.

Consumer complaint narrative:
We filed a fraud claim on XX/XX/XXXX with USBank after my identity was stolen and we were alerted to charges on our checking account that we did not make through XXXX. Our bank issued a provisional credit to our account of {$670.00} to cover the fraudulent charge pending their investigation. 
We received a letter from the bank on XX/XX/XXXX stating that their investigation found that we received benefit from the fraudulent transaction either by receiving services and/or merchandise. We did not receive any services or products and can prove that the product in question was never shipped by the company. As such, after their denial of our claim, the bank has now reversed the provisional credit from our account and we are now over drafting our account. We live paycheck to paycheck and this is greatly affecting our ability to pay for our living expenses. 
We have sent the documents stating that this product was never shipped to us to the fax number that was given to us by the Fraud Protection representatives at the bank, sent on XX/XX/XXXX. We have also made daily phone calls to this department starting XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX requesting updates on review of these documents and have also requested phone calls back to us each time we call. They state they have placed a call back to us but there was no answer on our end. No voice mail had been left for us to call back to. Each time we place a request, we are told it will take 24-48 hours to hear back, but to date, we have not spoken to an investigator as requested.

It seems to us that they are assuming we are guilty but we have no recourse in which to prove innocence. 
There is no phone number that we can reach someone directly who is doing the investigation of our claim and the fraud representatives seem to only be able to enter requests. 
We have also attempted multiple times to reach the company the fraudulent charge was placed with on XXXX and they have not replied to messages. I have placed a case with XXXX as well but have not heard back. 
We need help to resolve this issue and be reimbursed for this fraud that occurred on our account with US Bank.

Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Card was charged for something you did not purchase with the card
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I did a routine check of my credit card balances through Bank of America ( BoA ). During this check, I had noticed a suspicious pending charge from XX/XX/XXXX in the amount of {$590.00} on my Bank of America card ending in XXXX. After locking the card using the mobile app, I immediately reached out to the customer service fraud center at BoA to report this activity. The representative asked me several questions regarding this charge and I answered truthfully that I did not authorize and had no knowledge of this pending charge. The charge description showed that the event was called XXXX XXXX XXXX which appears to be an event that took place in XXXX in California based on a XXXX search. I had indicated to the representative, that I did not purchase any tickets for this event and did not give my card to anyone to do so. I never received any tickets or correspondence from this merchant. The representative assured me that this would be investigated and that the charge would be removed in the meantime. The representative said that they did not need any additional information from me at that time. The representative issued a new card ending in XXXX as expected in a case of possible fraud. I destroyed the old card in the meantime while waiting for a new card. The BoA claim ID is XXXX. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, I was sent a Bank of America email stating that the claim was complete, but Bank of America reversed their decision and re-applied the charge of {$590.00}. Bank of America indicated through the emailed letter that the charge was made on an approved device such as a cell phone or tablet. I immediately reached out to the Bank of America Fraud Center on XX/XX/XXXX for further explanation, but I was not provided any additional information outside of what was indicated on the letter. I went over the same details from the original call and was reassured that the claim would be reopened and more details will be provided under the original claim ID. I believe the representative also said that the charge would be removed again. As of this complaint that charge remains in place and I have received no new information from any Bank of America representative. 
While waiting for further feedback from Bank of America, I became more proactive and gathered more information on my end. The fraudulent transaction provided a contact website and phone number for a ticketing company called XXXX XXXX XXXX  I decided to reach out to their customer service on the evening of XX/XX/XXXX and spoke with a representative named XXXX. The representative was helpful and attempted to try and find more information about this charge. I provided my name, phone number, email, and the last 4 digits of the card that was charged. She was unable to find any transaction on their end matching any of my details. She agreed to send me an email confirming the phone call and also suspecting a fraudulent charge. 
The Bank of America credit card transaction details also state that the charge was made through the web ( credit card not present ). I only own two devices ( 1 cell phone and 1 laptop ). I only use the XXXX XXXX XXXX so I was able to retrieve my entire browsing history for all devices from the date of the charge. There are no web site visits to the ticketing company XXXX XXXX XXXX or any other ticketing agency. I also pulled up my XXXX location history that shows I did not travel on the date of the charge to California assuming the purchase was made for the music event in California. It should be noted that I have not traveled to California in at least 15 years. Bank of America will find no local California charges made in California during that time frame. 

I am concerned that Bank of America is accusing me of making a false claim of fraud, so I have reached out to my local police department in XXXX, CT and filed a report. I reiterated all the details to the officer assigned to make the report. The case # from the XXXX, CT Police is XXXX. 

I called Bank of America again on XX/XX/XXXX to see if there are any new updates, but still haven't received anything regarding this re-opened claim ID. The charge remains and the mobile app and website indicate the claim is still " complete ''. I did provide the police case number to the representative as new information. The representative says it is still pending but again reassured me that it will be resolved. I have greatly increased my BOA account settings and according to their website metrics, I am almost at the highest level of security to prevent unauthorized access. Bank of America had indicated in their claim denial that they considered my account history. It should note that I have been a Bank of America customer for roughly 20 years with 2 credit cards in active use. This was the first time that I have seen a fraudulent charge on either account and would hope that Bank of America would take this into account and remove this fraudulent charge as assured by several fraud center representatives. I am concerned that my accounts with Bank of America are not secure and have locked all BoA accounts with them for the time being.

Sub-issue: Can't use card to make purchases
Consumer complaint narrative:
The fraud department of my XXXX XXXX card turned my husband and me into dishonest people who never paid XXXX to the XXXX XXXX XXXX for their ride from XXXX XXXX to XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXXXXXX  ) and XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
The problem started on XX/XX/XXXXXXXX  when Citi declined a payment for an online train ticket purchase from XXXX XXXX because of suspected fraud. I called from my phone with my XXXX XXXX number, and was not able to verify my identity because I didnt have my bank account number or the number of another Citi card with me. Fair enough. So I went to the train station and paid for the tickets with my XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
It then occurred to me that I could maybe still use that card though XXXX XXXX, so I used XXXX XXXX to pay for a small drugstore purchase on XX/XX/XXXX, and that went through. So I used XXXX XXXX for the round trip ticket XXXX XXXX which I purchased from the bus conductor as we entered the bus. When I saw that this charge was declined after we arrived in XXXX, I called Citi again, and this time identity verification worked as they texted a code to my US phone number. I was told that block on my card was lifted and that I could use my card again. So I made used it at a coffee shop on XX/XX/XXXX with no problem. But then the charge to the XXXXXXXX XXXX company which they resubmitted on XX/XX/XXXX and on XX/XX/XXXX was again declined. Exasperated, I decided to wait until I got home to sort this out. 
I called Citi from my US phone number when I got home, explained the situation about the XXXX Bus charge, but verification entailed remembering a special word that I had forgotten. My card was again blocked and was told a code would be sent to me by mail. I asked if this could be reversed by a supervisor. It seems that no human can override what was clearly a computer generated nonsensical decision. How many people are honest enough to call to make sure a payment goes through in a foreign country after they have used a service, when the ticket was just a slip of paper with no identifying information on it? 
I called Citi again today with the code, my card was reactivated, but I was told that the charge to the XXXX XXXX XXXX would be paid when they resubmit that charge. They have already resubmitted that charge 5 times and I dont know if they will resubmit it again. 
So that is how we, an honest couple in their early XXXX, were turned into a free-loaders though the inanity of computer generated decisions that can not be overridden by an intelligent human being.

Citibank LL Bean Master Card XXXX  : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Issued to XXXX, XXXX XXXX, exp date XX/XX/XXXX. 

This complaint is against Citibank, the issuers of the LL Bean Master Card. I got the LL Bean master card application/filled out, at the checkout counter, at LL Bean where I have been shopping for over XXXX  years. 

CITI SENDS ME THE CARD THEN DENIED CHARGE SAYING I NEED TO BE VERIFIED. 
It arrived last week, and Sunday, XX/XX/XXXX, I had made XXXX charges at XXXX, then went to pick up, and pay for my dogs grooming, at XXXX. At XXXX, Citibank denied my charge card. I tried it XXXX  times, and it was still denied. I have been going to XXXX, in XXXX, since XXXX, to have my dog groomed. Talk about a red face?? 

I used a different card, to pay for the dogs grooming, XXXX more reliable than Citibank LL Bean Master Card. 

When I got home, yesterday ( Sunday ), I called the XXXX customer service line, XXXX and I asked the agent why my new card had been denied at the register? 

I was told by the agent, I hadnt been verified yet. Hellooooo, earth calling Citibank would the intelligent among us, have verified me, before they even sent me the card???? 

I told the agent, I wanted them to send me a bill for what I owe, and I wanted the credit card cancelled. She responded that I can not CANCEL the card, even if I pay it off ( +- {$1000.00} due at this point, ), until they verify me. 

I called again, this morning ( Monday ), and was told the same thing. 

What I am asking the consumer financial protection bureaus help with. 

XXXX The bank behind this credit card, has the horse in front of the cart you verify a person, before you send a card out! Sending out a card, before verifying a person, is putting the person who owns that name, at financial risk, when Citi doesnt do a thorough job, before sending out credit cards. This sending of cards, to unverified people XXXX, should be a fineable offense. Its flat out, a dangerous policy. 

XXXX told the agent I wanted a final statement sent to me, immediately, which I would pay then I wanted the card cancelled, as its unreliable. The agent said I could not cancel/close the account, until I verified myself, WHAT???? I want the CFPB, to require that Citibank, send me a final statement, asap. I will pay that off. 

XXXX. I want CFPB to require that Citibank, CLOSE that card account, and notify all XXXX credit agencies ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ), that the account is closed, At the request of the card holder. 

I can not afford to do business, with a bank ( Citibank ), that is so slip-shod, and unreliable in its processes, that it sends credit cards out, BEFORE THEY HAVE EVEN VERIFIED A PERSON! 

That puts the credit rating, and financial safety, of the real owner of the name at risk when Citi does such a poor job of verification after the fact when whoever has already been issued a card.

Sub-issue: Problem using a debit or ATM card
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my deep frustration with the handling of a clear account takeover incident on my Wells Fargo account and the repeated denial of my claim. The events that have transpired since XX/XX/XXXX, alongside the numerous missed opportunities for intervention, have not only left me with a significant financial loss but also highlight systemic failures in fraud prevention and customer support. 

On XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX XXXX, I received a call appearing to be from Wells Fargo ( per CallerID ). The caller, who I now know was a scammer, verified my account through an authentication code sent to my phone ( by Wells Fargo system ) and alerted me to suspicious activity. While on the call, I pulled up my account and noted four declined charges, which he assured me were part of the fraudulent activity he would secure by issuing a new card. At that time, I hadnt realized my debit card was missing, thinking Id misplaced it at home. The scammer, who used highly detailed Wells Fargo contact center scripting, collected my cards PIN, the last four of my Social Security number, and the last four of my account number under the guise of account security. He even initiated a relay to send additional codes to my phone, which I unknowingly provided, giving him full access to make unauthorized transactions. While I believed my account was secure, an associate of his proceeded to make charges totaling {$10000.00} using my card. Later that evening, suspecting something was amiss, I contacted Wells Fargo only to discover that the call had not come from the bank. That there were additional charges on my account not currently in despite, and I was distraught. Despite the Caller ID showing Wells Fargo, they had no record of this call. I immediately reported the fraud, expecting prompt action. However, the response was underwhelming. My card was only reported stolen, and no further action was taken to suspend the account or escalate the case despite assurances to the contrary. Following are key interactions that illustrate my experience and further demonstrate the gaps in your
response : XX/XX/XXXX : I called again at XXXX XXXX, only to find no complaint or case notes lodged from the previous night. I had to escalate my complaint again, insisting on a formal investigation and restitution. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I called to check on the status of my complaint, only to find no documentation on my case. Once more, I escalated the issue, expecting a response from the account takeover team. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I received a letter denying my claim, stating no suspicious activity was found. This decision was in direct contradiction to the evidence I provided. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I called to understand the denial rationale, speaking to a representative named XXXX, who gave no satisfactory explanation, so I escalated to XXXX. She mentioned the claim was denied because I had legitimate transactions between the fraudulent ones. These were unrelated, as they were online bill payments and not connected to the disputed debit card transactions. This lead to my case being reopened by a supervisor ( XXXX ). 

XX/XX/XXXX : I learned that despite multiple escalations, the account takeover investigation had only been officially initiated on XX/XX/XXXX. By this time, nearly a month had passed since the initial fraud incident. 

XX/XX/XXXX : My claim was denied again with a dismissive explanation that the charges had been verified by Fraud Detection, stating calls originated from my phone. This blanket response disregards the facts of the account takeover and the manipulation involved.

Throughout this process, I raised valid concerns : 1. Why did four charges get approved after four were declined on my account without any intervention or account suspension? Most financial institutions require you to call when declined charges occur.

2. Why wasnt I alerted immediately after the multiple declined transactions, as other banks typically require verification before further transactions?

3. How can you ensure this wasnt an internal breach given the level of detail in the scammers approach, which closely mirrored Wells Fargos scripting and procedures? 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a secure email stating the denial of my claim for the same reason. This response is dismissive and fails to address the core issues : a breach of security protocols, failure to protect the account despite multiple warning signs, and neglect in promptly suspending my account after declined charges. I have asked Wells Fargo to : 1. Conduct a comprehensive investigation into the internal processes and to provide evidence that my account was not accessed improperly. 2. Provide a full refund of the {$10000.00} given the banks failure to prevent this fraudulent activity despite clear red flags. 3. Reinforce account security protocols to ensure that such breaches do not happen in the future.

As I am now on my fourth denial, two original letters without a phone call explanation, and two secured emails, I have not yet received my request nor have I been protected as a consumer nor have I been assured that all preventative actions are in place for future consumers. I've not been taken seriously and need the CFPB to reconsider your stance on this matter. I am seeking immediate resolution and restitution to recover my stolen funds.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative: The property was Listed for short sale. A contract for purchase and sale was executed between buyer and seller with approval of a Listing Agent, Buyer 's Agent, their brokers, and the homeowner 's foreclosure defense attorney. Authorization documents, along with the initial offer package was submitted. At that time a workout package was requested, which was to include a demand for any hardship documentation from the homeowner. However, a senior level mitigator responded back rejecting the homeowner 's foreclosure defense attorney and the buyer 's agent Authorization To Release documents after all parties designated those two individuals to work together on behalf of the buyer and seller, siting company policy, not because the documents were incomplete or filled out incorrectly. The mitigator stated they would only work with the listing agent. That was the only reason given. That mitigator also copied the listing agent on the communication, which violated the Cease & Desist, Homeowner Do Not Contact, and Realtor Do Not Contact documents submitted by the attorney. We can find nothing from the XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX and in legal statute that gives the lenders servicer the right to make this demand. They however have a legal responsibility to try and negotiate a default workout resolution with the parties, and the parties have a legal right to appoint their chosen legal representatives. A servicer should not have the right to make that demand.

I again called my insurance company and asked them to send something to Shellpoint, They stated they had sent something to Shellpoint verifying coverage but would send it again. On XX/XX/XXXX I received my escrow analysis for the year. It stated that I had a shortage of {$2000.00}. This shortage would increase my payments from the {$520.00} I have been paying to {$590.00} a month. I called Shellpoint again and asked why my shortage was so significant. The customer service representative made me aware that Shellpoint Mortgage paid my insurance twice in the last year. Once it was paid in XX/XX/year> {$1400.00} and then again in XX/XX/year> {$1400.00}. I was told to resolve the issue I would need to contact my insurance company and have a refund issued, While on the phone I asked why I was still receiving letters about coverage in XX/XX/year> because the insurance company has sent the verification. They again told me they haven't received anything from my insurance company : I called my insurance company and spoke with them about refunding the overpayment. They had already issued a check and sent it to Shellpoint. I again asked if they could send something to Shellpoint proving I had coverage for XXXX. They stated they have sent documents to them several times but would again. The insurance refund finally was applied to my account on XX/XX/XXXX. I called Shellpoint Mortgage again to request another escrow analysis since the refund was now in my escrow account. That analysis was done on XX/XX/XXXX. When I reviewed the analysis it showed my payments were going to increase again to {$600.00} a month. I called Shellpoint again and questioned why it was going to increase more when there was a refund made for the double payment of my insurance and I hadn't even made a payment of {$590.00} yet. I was told by the representative that is just the what it would be if I wanted to stay current on my mortgage payments I would have to pay the amount. I noticed they based the analysis off of the {$590.00} payment that was due in XXXX. I told the representative I hadn't even made a payment for that amount yet and how could a correct analysis be done based off of a payment I hadn't made. I questioned the amount to be paid in XXXX because it wasn't the right amount. The representative told me after reviewing the analysis from XXXX Shellpoint forgot to apply a {$15.00} charge and that is why my monthly payments where going to increase again in XXXX. I asked that a new escrow analysis be done based off of the {$520.00} amount I had been making for the year of 2024. The representative told me the analysis would be done on XX/XX/XXXX and someone would call me from Shellpoint to go over it with me since there had been so many problems with my account. I never received another escrow analysis, nothing was updated online and no one had called me. I again called Shellpoint to find out what was-going on with my account because the XXXX payment of {$590.00} was due on the XXXX. I was told by the representative that the escrow analysis request was in their system but now would be done by XX/XX/XXXX. I questioned the amount of the XXXX payment because it wasn't correct. It was based off of the shortage when the insurance was double paid by Shellpoint. The representative told me I would have to pay the {$590.00} to stay current on my mortgage payments. She told me that I have a grace period and could wait until the XXXX to review the new analysis without any penalties. I asked if someone would contact me to go over the analysis still. The representative told me that they don't contact people about their analysis. I explained to her the last person I spoke to told me someone would contact me. She apologized that I was misinformed. I asked about the insurance coverage in XXXX. The representative told me that it has been removed from my account because they received verification from my insurance company. 
I still haven't received the escrow analysis I requested because of the double payment of insurance and the calculations being based off of a payment that wasn't made until XX/XX/year>. I have made the payment for XXXX of {$590.00}. I know this amount isn't correct. I will now have to pay {$600.00} in XXXX. I would like for a correct analysis to be done and the opportunity to pay the shortage. I have considered paying the shortage on the XX/XX/XXXX analysis but I know it isn't correct either. 
I have been yelled at, talked over, told that is just how it is, misinformed and lied to by Shellpoint when I call them. I can't seem to get help when calling Shellpoint or anything resolved. They just keep telling me this how it is when I know my escrow account is incorrect and my monthly payment amount is incorrect.
