He connected me to someone seemed like from Citicards ( # shown as Citi XXXX @ XXXX ), the lady asked me to confirm my personal infor in order to mail my new credit card. I now don't remember what infor she asked me to confirm. 

When done w/her phone call, he called me back @ XXXX XXXX, said his name is XXXX XXXX and he's assigned to my case, and that when I receive new card I should call his direct number XXXX, he will remove all the fraud charges and get credit back to my acct. He then asked me to call his direct number to make sure he receives my call, I did so at XXXX XXXX. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I signed on but couldnt access my online acct for card XXXX, it was closed. 

From Monday XX/XX/XXXX to XXXX  XXXX : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX several times ( the # shown as Toll Free Call XXXX ) to see if I receive my new card. 

XX/XX/XXXX : XXXX XXXX ( called from XXXX @ XXXX XXXX  ) asked me to call him as soon as new card arrives so he can remove the fraud charges and issue credit to my acct. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I received the new card ( card ending # XXXX ) and activated it. I then called XXXX XXXX at XXXX @ XXXX XXXX  in hope that the fraud charges will be taken care of. He asked me to hang up and he called me back from XXXX @ XXXX XXXX. 
I don't remember what infor he asked from me. He said he needed the full credit card number in order to remove the fraud charges and issue credit to my acct. 
He then asked for my home phone then he called my home phone from XXXX @ XXXX XXXX  at the same time he told me to leave my cell phone on. He instructed me that I will receive ID Code from Citi and I should read them to him, he said he needs these codes to remove the fraud charges and issue credit back to my acct. 
I read the codes to him. He even told me to enter a long number into a text message and send, the number is XXXX, he said it's part of the process to remove the fraud charges. Right after I sent the text, a phone call to my cell shown as XXXX XXXX XXXX at XXXX XXXX  called and hung up right away. 

After staying on the phone with XXXX XXXX for about XXXX min, that was almost XXXX XXXX  XXXX, I asked him why it took so long. His answer was because he worked from home and didn't have the regular gadgets as in the office and that's the reasons it took long and that he had to fill out application. Dear Officer of Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) My name is XXXX XXXX, living in XXXX XXXX, CA XXXX. Ive lived in XXXX for more than 42 years and never moved out of XXXX and never experienced hurricane. 

XXXX VACATION SCAM DISPUTE 1 ) On XX/XX/XXXX I searched for 1st time XXXX vacation with XXXX. Its website does not mention anything about XXXX is a hurricane season. So I booked a vacation for two to XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX for {$2700.00}. 

2 ) On XX/XX/XXXX : I tried to call XXXX Vacations to cancel my vacation due to severe hurricane season ( hurricane Helene hit XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX and caused heavy damage in XXXX ). No live agent. I talked to robot and got disconnected twice. 

3 ) Then I had to use chat. Only chat robot was online. I got disconnected twice.

4 ) Chat referred me back to online cancellation. No live agent to help me.

5 ) I had to cancel online. Their system was designed to take money only, no other reason for cancellation is considered. After I clicked cancel my vacation theyre not going to refund my money. 

6 ) On XX/XX/XXXX, at XXXX XXXX : I called Citi XXXX to report that scam and open dispute the whole amount of {$2700.00}. 

7 ) Then from XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX hurricane Milton hit XXXX and caused heavy damage. 

8 ) On XX/XX/XXXX : I called Citi XXXX to follow up with my dispute. Citis rep told me a letter was sent to me on XX/XX/XXXX and asked me to wait. 

9 ) On XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX AM : I called Citi XXXX 2nd time to follow up on existing dispute of {$2700.00} with XXXX Vacations scam. 

10 ) Citis rep again told me that a letter was sent out on XX/XX/XXXX, but I have not received it as of XX/XX/XXXX. Also I signed up for online communication but why the letter sent XX/XX/XXXX was not online. I asked Citis rep to email me that letter ; he said it would take 48 hrs. to process my request. It seems that Citi XXXX did not want to help me at all and wanted to force me to pay for that scam. 

11 ) On XX/XX/XXXX : After 3 days and I have not received any email from Citi XXXX. So I called Citi XXXX again at XXXXXXXX XXXX. The rep promised to send postal mail and email again. Call ended at XXXX XXXX 

This is a SCAM because if the website warned that XXXX is hurricane season, I would not have booked vacation in XXXX. Basically, anyone booked would have lost money 100 % because who would want to risk their lives going to XXXX during hurricane season. 

Lets say XXXX people booked XXXX vacation package with XXXX in XXXX, each cost averagely {$3000.00} ; 50 % bought vacation insurance ( {$300.00} x XXXX = {$450000.00} ) ; 50 % did not ( {$3000.00} x XXXX = {>= $1,000,000} ) So, when hurricane ( s ) hit that area, how many people do you think would be so stupid to still go into the Center of hurricane ( s ) for vacation? I think NONE. 

Then, XXXX would get a total FREE money of {>= $1,000,000} ( XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX dollars ) from cancelled vacations. 

How would you say its not a BIG SCAM??? 

So I would like to report this SCAM ( from XXXX ) and BAD BUSINESS practice ( from Citi XXXX citi.com ) to your agency for help resolving the matter. Also to prevent this from happening to others, I think the Government should do something about it. 

Thank you for your time and Im looking forward to your response. 

Best regards, XXXX XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am sending to address the adverse marks on my credit file that have been attributed to me. While I would willingly acknowledge and assume responsibility for any valid debts, I am unable to do so in this case without Proper Validation and Proof Of Claim. As per the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I am formally requesting comprehensive validation of the alleged debt. 

I seek evidence establishing that I am the party obligated to settle this debt and that there exists a legally binding contractual obligation compelling me to do so. For clarity, I request that all communication be limited to written correspondence until adequate validation of the purported debt is provided. To assist you in meeting this request, please furnish the following required documentation : Complete payment history, as per the precedent set by Spears v Brennan, 745 N.E.2d 862 ; XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. Provide a detailed verification by line item, including information on the purchase date, itemized amounts, receipt of goods, and any relevant details directly from the Original Creditor. 
Date of Last Activity. 
Full, accurate social security number that may help to identify me as the correct person you are trying to collect from. 
Agreement that bears the signature of the alleged debtor, indicating the commitment to pay the original creditor. 
The obligation between your company XXXX XXXX, SUNRISE CREDIT SERVICE, XXXX  and me that authorizes the collection of the alleged debt, along with any transactions binding me to an agreement to pay your company. 

Proof of photo identification ( i.e., driver 's license, state identification card, or other government issued identification card ) presented at the time of incurring the debt. 
Letter of sale or assignment from the original creditor to your company, including any agreement with your client granting the authority to collect on this alleged debt. ( Agreement with your client that grants you the authority to collect on this alleged debt. ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ) - information relating to the purchase of a bad debt is not proprietary or burdensome. 
Any other pertinent information regarding the creation of the debt by your collection agency like ( 1. Where the debt originated from, 2. ) The sum paid by the bad debt buyer for the plaintiff 's debt, 3. ) How the total amount was determined, and 4 ) A list of documents that authorize the collection of debts. )

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing regarding a notice I received from your agency concerning the referenced account. Pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), Section 809 ( b ) [ 15 U.S.C. 1692g ], I am requesting written validation of the alleged debt.

Please provide the following information : 1. **Verification of the debt : ** - The amount of the debt and how it was calculated.

- The name of the original creditor.

- Copies of any contracts or agreements that outline my responsibility for this debt.

2. **Proof of your authority to collect the debt : ** - Documentation showing that your agency is authorized to collect on this account.

3. **Details of payments and charges : ** - An itemized statement of all payments made on this account, including dates and amounts.

- Evidence of the debt 's ownership, including a complete chain of title.

Please consider this letter a formal dispute of the debt. While I await your response, you must cease all collection activities, including reporting this account to credit reporting agencies. Under the FDCPA, collection activity on a disputed debt is prohibited until validation is provided.

If you can not provide sufficient validation, I request that you cease all further collection attempts and notify all relevant credit reporting agencies to delete any reported information about this debt. 

Please respond to this request in writing at the address provided above. I will need at least 30 days to review the validation once it is received. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Timeline In XX/XX/XXXX, I leased a XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX ) from XXXX XXXX in XXXXXXXX XXXX. The sticker price was {$62000.00}. Within XXXX weeks, I started experiencing issues with the car. While driving the car, it completely shut off. I was forced to turn down a street and use my emergency brake as the brakes did not work. When I brought it to the dealership, I was told that nothing was wrong with the car. In XXXX, I got a letter in the mail stating that there was a recall for an electrical issue. The dealership denied any wrongdoing As the weather turned colder ( Fall/Winter XXXX ) the electric mode started to fail so it was only allowing gas use. After many more back-and-forth trips to the dealership, I was eventually told that the electric mode simply does not work when it is cold out. I tried to go through XXXX XXXX who offered trade assistance to get out of the car. I was then told that there was over $ XXXX in negative equity just after 6 months of owning the car. Needless to say, I did not go that route. 

The car worked ok during the summer but around XX/XX/XXXX the car 's electric mode failed again. To make things worse, the car felt like it was " bucking '' and not running correctly. Again, after much back and forth from the dealership, I was told that nothing could be done unless a check engine light came on. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, the check engine light did come on and through diagnostics, I was told that it was going to cost {$25000.00} to fix the vehicle. Although this is covered under warranty, I continue to have concerns over the safety of the vehicle, given the history of issues experienced. I once again requested that I be let out of my lease but they forced me to take the car back. After driving it off the lot, I noticed that the electric mode still did not work but I was told that the $ XXXX repairs did not address that issue. I attached the response from the dealership. 

I tried once again over the winter ( XXXX ) to get the car returned but the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX denied my request. 

This summer, the car had various problems such as shaking while going over bumps and the touch screen freezing. I was told that it needed more repairs but they can not provide a loaner. I am still trying to figure out a way to drop it off and still have transportation. 

This XXXX, I received a letter in the mail informing me of a new recall. This time it stated that the car was a potential fire hazard. I have attached the letter to the email. There is currently no fix for this recall and per the letter, I am not to park it near any buildings or other vehicles. I am still expected to make my lease payment. 

I had been working with a Lemon Law Lawyer ( no cost to me ). I was told that XXXX ( XXXX XXXX ) had access to my warranty history but upon requesting ( myself and the law firm ) it, we were both told that it would not be released without a subpoena. The lawyer ( XXXX XXXX XXXX has mentioned that it would be a good idea and would help my case if the story was shared. 

As of today, my husband and I still refuse to drive the vehicle with our children in it. I find it to be more than reasonable to simply return the car and be let out of my lease without penalty.

Issue: Took or threatened to take negative or legal action
Sub-issue: Sued you without properly notifying you of lawsuit
Consumer complaint narrative:
Velocity Investments LLC, is suing me for an alleged debt I do not owe them. My original creditor has charged and written off this debt. No where in my original contract did I read that this debt can be sued for, in fact I never went through mediation with the original creditor nor was it offered by velocity investments LLC. I requested on plea paperwork a motion for discovery the following items within 30 days : 1. Master purchase agreement - showing contract governing the assignment or sale of the alleged debt. This is warranted to confirm the right to sue as I never was given an opportunity to go through mediation or was offered.

2. Signed contracts - all signed contracts or agreements between myself and the original creditor or between myself and their agency.

3. Affidavit of responsibility - signed affidavit sworn under penalty of perjury by the individual who is personally responsible for the daily accounting and maintenance of this particular account,
attesting to the accuracy and completeness of the account records.

4. Original Credit Agreement - original credit agreement or any document evidencing the credit relationship between myself and the original creditor.

5. Validation of debt - validation of debt including any calculations correspondence or proof of debt amount.

6. Documents evidencing charge-off or written off debt by original creditor, including relevant account statements.

7. All documents showing assignment or transfer of debt from the original creditor to the plaintiff.

8. Communication records- showing communication between myself and upstart and myself and velocity investments LLC including any including letters, emails, phone call logs.

9. Internal notes - internal notes, memos, or records maintained by your agency relating to this accounts history.

10. Documentation of the plaintiffs authority to bring the current lawsuit, including any agreements or assignments. 

I also requested for interrogatories.

1. Identify the date in which the plaintiff acquired the debt in question and the source from which it was acquired.

2. Provide a full chain of title for the debt from the original creditor to the plaintiff.

3. State whether the plaintiff has any records showing the debt was ever charged off or written off by the original creditor.

Additionally, all documents were requested in good faith and I have yet to receive a response from Velocity Investment, LLC and will now have to go to court soon. I asked for these documents because I understand the laws that protect me especially the The FDCPA is the fair debt collection practices act, which is a federal law generally requires debt collectors to provide clear and accurate information about the debt, which could be interpreted to necessitate details beyond a simple Bill of sale and effectively requires aspects of the purchase agreement to demonstrate the debts origin & ownership of transfer.

Without all of the requested information what velocity investments LLC is doing can be seen as a direct violation of my rights under the FDCPA. If the said purchase agreement can not be provided, after it is mentioned in the bill of sale I can only assume Velocity Investments LLC is intentionally not providing the requested document as they have no true legal right to sue or collect.

I remember the day I received the notification of the fraudulent charges, as I had just used the credit card at my local XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX  stores before being notified of 3 other charges that I hadn't made, and I assumed someone must have gotten my card details somehow. Since, no communication stating receipt was received, I proceeded to write a letter to the supervisor with a follow up to what was agreed on securing my data against retaliation and compliance process. Three subsequent letters have been received and only the one by the supervisor on XX/XX/XXXX does it mention detailed actions that will be taken. Additionally, in the last letter received from legal, they communicated and disclosed for the first time that a personal electronic device ( phone ) was used to carry official business. Issue: Took or threatened to take negative or legal action
Sub-issue: Threatened or suggested your credit would be damaged
Consumer complaint narrative: My name is XXXX XXXX and I am writing in response to the recent communication received from your agency regarding an alleged debt. This letter serves as a formal debt validation request pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 U.S.C. 1692g. I am exercising my rights under the FDCPA to request the following information : 1. Validation of the Debt : Please provide detailed documentation verifying the validity of the alleged debt, including the original creditor 's name, the account number, the date of the last payment, the original balance, and a complete payment history. I also request copies of any agreements or contracts pertaining to the alleged debt. 2. Cease and Desist Communication : Pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1692c, I am requesting that you cease all communication with me in relation to this debt, except as specifically allowed under the FDCPA. This includes communication through telephone calls, letters, emails, or any other medium. According to 15 U.S.C. 1692a ( 2 ), communication includes the conveying of information regarding a debt directly or indirectly to any person through any medium, including the reporting of information to a credit reporting agency. Therefore, I specifically request that you cease all communication through the medium of my credit report. 3. Licensing Information : I request that you provide documentation establishing that your agency is licensed to collect debt in my state. Please include a copy of your current license or registration, as required by applicable laws and regulations. Additionally, I request information regarding your agency 's license to collect debt in your state. Please provide documentation demonstrating that your agency is duly licensed to operate as a debt collector in your state. 4. Errors and Omissions Insurance : As a professional debt collection agency, I request that you provide your agency 's errors and omissions insurance information. Please provide the name of your insurance provider, the policy number, and any other relevant details. 5. Bill of Assignment : I request that you provide a complete and valid bill of assignment or sale, demonstrating that the alleged debt was legally assigned or transferred to your agency. This document should include the name and contact information of the original creditor, the date of assignment, and any accompanying documentation supporting the transfer of ownership. Please note that failure to provide the requested information within [ 30 days or a reasonable time frame according to local laws ] from the date of receipt of this letter will result in the presumption that the debt is invalid and unenforceable. Furthermore, any continued attempts to collect this debt without providing the requested validation will be considered a violation of the FDCPA. I request that all future communication regarding this debt be conducted in writing and sent to the address provided above. This is to ensure accurate record-keeping and to protect my rights under the FDCPA. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I expect your cooperation in providing the requested documentation within the designated time frame. Please be advised that any further contact that does not comply with the FDCPA after receipt of this letter will be reported to the appropriate authorities and subject to litigation without further notice
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Sub-issue: Didn't receive enough information to verify debt
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this formal complaint against EASTERN account system inc, with the CFPB due to their attempts to collect a debt whose validity has not been verified, despite my repeated requests for documentation and verification in accordance with the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). The FDCPA grants consumers the right to request validation and verification of any claimed debt and requires the creditor to provide adequate documentation proving the legitimacy of said debt.

In response to the collection notice received on XX/XX/year>, I formally contacted Eastern to request full validation of this debt under the FDCPA. In my letter, tracked with reference number XXXX, I detailed the required documentation, including a copy of the original agreement, the name and address of the current creditor, a breakdown of charges and interest, and confirmation that the debt falls within the statute of limitations. However, to date, Eastern has responded only with a copy of a bill in my name, which does not meet the legal standards for debt validation. This incomplete response does not allow me to assess the validity of the debt nor confirm that the amount claimed is accurate and attributable to me.

Requests for Intervention : Immediate Block on Credit Bureau Reporting : Since Eastern has failed to fulfill its obligation to provide complete debt validation as required by the FDCPA, I request that the CFPB intervene to block any attempt by Eastern to report this debt to credit bureaus. Until Eastern meets the validation requirements set forth by the FDCPA, they should not be permitted to take any action that could impact my credit history.

Suspension of All Collection Actions Until Debt Validation : Under the FDCPA, Eastern is required to cease all collection actions until the debt is properly validated. I ask that the CFPB take steps to ensure that Eastern halts all collection efforts and any further contact with me or third parties until complete documentation is provided.

Strict Compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : The FCRA mandates that any information reported to credit bureaus be accurate and verifiable. Since Eastern has not provided the requested debt verification, this debt does not meet the FCRAs requirements for accuracy and verifiability. I therefore request that the CFPB take action to prevent Eastern from reporting this debt until its legitimacy is fully established.

Application of Sanctions as Provided by Law : Due to Easterns failure to provide the necessary information within the legally required timeframe and in accordance with FDCPA requirements, I ask that the CFPB consider all available sanctions and corrective measures to ensure that Eastern meets its obligations for transparency and accuracy in debt management. 
Sincerely XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company disputes the facts presented in the complaint
Company: Eastern Account Systems of Connecticut, Inc.

Sub-issue: Account opened without my consent or knowledge
Consumer complaint narrative:
I received in the mail from NETSPEND XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX A bank card with my name, and a routing number XXXX and account number XXXX a bank name : XXXX XXXX. 

I had never contacting this bank and have no desire for a new bank card and account with a company I know nothing about and have no relationship with. 

Looking at the one page letter with this information and physical card, which has a XX/XX/year> expiration another account XXXX -different from the earlier bank account, suggesting this is an additional credit card account. 

This letter has no 'contact us to remove your name from our database ' or any way to confirm an account is actually no already in existence. That is to say, it is saying this account exists, going as far as to state " provide this rounting number and account number to your employer to set up direct deposit. '' To me this whole letter sets off a chain of concern about identify theft and what actions now I need to take to figure out if there are other accounts in my name -as well as how this NETSPEND/ XXXX XXXX  XXXX bank have my personal information and created a credit card in my name. For context, this year our mail was stolen, including a bank statement, and with just that statement, theives started direct withdrawals from our account having just our account number and routing number. We had to close our account, open a new one, and update all our direct payment services for water, garbage, energy, credit cards. This is to say having a routing number and account number to a bank account I have never establish arriving in the mail is a serious concern. Especially since I have no way to contact this company. All the paper has besides the po box address is a QR code to " Scan to Verify Your Identity '' This is to say, I am sure if I try to contact them other than by snail mail, they will have to 'verify my identiy ' to talk to anyone, and thereby inadvertently trick individuals to confirming I am a willing partner in their scam to establish a unsolicited account and credit card. 

Please take action against this company. While I am a savvy individual, I am sure other people are trying to contact this company to say they do not want to receive further communication and thereby from this company 's perspective via an 'identify verification ' setting up the account.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Escalated Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Reporting of Cancelled Debt by MACYS/CBNA To Whom It May Concern, I am filing this escalated complaint regarding the continued reporting of a cancelled debt by MACYS/CBNA ( Account ending in XXXX ) on my credit report with XXXX and XXXX, despite the issuance of a Form 1099-C documenting the cancellation of this debt. 

Key Issues and Violations 1. Continued Reporting of Cancelled Debt : MACYS/CBNA issued a Form 1099-C for {$3100.00}, indicating that the debt was cancelled as of XX/XX/year>. 
The continued reporting of this debt as charged off on my credit report contradicts the identifiable event of cancellation as documented in the 1099-C. This inconsistency violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which mandates maximum possible accuracy in credit reporting.

2. Failure to Update Credit Reporting : Despite the identifiable event of cancellation, XXXX and XXXX continue to list this account as charged off, with no indication of the debt being cancelled. 
Reporting a debt as both charged off and cancelled is misleading and harmful to my creditworthiness.

3. Misrepresentation of Debt Status : The issuance of a 1099-C signifies that the creditor has discharged the debt, which should result in its removal or accurate update on credit reports. Failure to do so misrepresents the legal status of the debt, potentially violating the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. 1692e ). 
4. Harm to Creditworthiness : This inaccurate reporting significantly impacts my credit score and financial opportunities. The continued derogatory reporting is unjustified given the cancellation of the debt. 

Requested Resolution To resolve this matter, I respectfully request that the CFPB : 1. Investigate MACYS/CBNAs compliance with FCRA and FDCPA regulations regarding the reporting of this account.

2. Require MACYS/CBNA to instruct XXXX and XXXX to remove the derogatory information related to this account from my credit report.

3. Provide written confirmation that the inaccurate information has been corrected or removed from my credit report.

Supporting Documentation To support this complaint, I have attached : A copy of the Form 1099-C issued by MACYS/CBNA for this account. 
My credit report highlighting the continued reporting of this account as charged off. 

Contact Information Full Name : XXXX XXXX Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, TN XXXX Phone Number : XXXX Email Address : XXXX I request that this matter be addressed promptly and that a resolution is provided within the mandated timeframe for investigations. I reserve the right to seek damages under applicable consumer protection laws for any continued inaccuracies. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

[ Barclays Bank Delaware ] [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] [ XXXX, DE, XXXX ] Re : Account Number : [ XXXX ] To Whom It XXXX Concern, I am writing in response to your recent communication concerning the above-referenced account. I formally request validation and verification of this alleged debt under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 U.S.C. 1692g. 
Please provide me with the following information : XXXX. Assignment Contract : A complete copy of the assignment or purchase agreement between your agency and the original creditor, showing that you have the legal authority to collect on this debt. 
XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX : The name and address of the original creditor, as well as the original account number. 
XXXX. Detailed Accounting : A full and detailed accounting of the alleged debt, including a breakdown of all charges, fees, and interest added to the account after it was allegedly assigned to you. 
XXXX. Proof of Ownership : Evidence that the debt was sold or transferred to you, including any documents demonstrating that the original creditor transferred rights to collect this debt to your agency. 
XXXX. XXXX of XXXX : Documentation showing the accurate amount of the debt and the validity of the debt as required by law. This includes all statements or billing records that reflect the original balance and all payments made. 
XXXX. Affidavit of the Debt : A sworn affidavit from an authorized agent of your agency attesting to the accuracy of the debt and your legal right to collect. 
This request is not only for verification but also to ensure that you are compliant with the FDCPA and that my rights as a consumer are protected. I expect a timely response within the XXXX period as prescribed by law. 
Please note that I am specifically requesting this information be sent directly to me and not processed through any automated dispute systems, such as e-OSCAR. It is imperative that you provide the exact documentation as requested above. 
If your agency can not provide the requested information, you are required by law to cease collection efforts and notify all relevant credit bureaus to remove any reference to this alleged debt from my credit report

The rep informed me they are in Utah as if that gives them the right to use these unfair deceptive, bait and switch rent a bank scams on unsuspecting consumers. They are giving me no other options here than to file this complaint and informed me they have no complaint process and they would not have anyone else contact me. They also told me they act independently from Regions so there is nothing the parent company can do for me. They were not able to tell me who regulates them or who I could contact other than FDIC which is odd to me and FDIC is not who I should contact for there violations of the TILA and UDAAP. As it stands today I do not see how the TILA I have would suffice to inform a consumer fairly.

All I want to be able to do is pay my loan on time and have The appropriate amounts be applied to both principal and interest and to be given a way to pay down sooner.

I also filed an fcra dispute as they are not reporting this as a closed end installment loan but rather a line of credit which this is not. Consumer complaint narrative:
On or about XX/XX/XXXX, I received a Experian Credit profile alert that Innovative Recovery ( IR ) had flagged my credit record. I had not conducted business with this company, received any past communication from them and thought it was fraud/or identity theft. 
I contacted the credit bureau and obtain the debt collector 's name and address. On XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, I mailed Innovative Recovery an initial dispute letter advising them that I disputed the validity of the debt and requested, the following information : 1.The amount of the debt ; 2 The name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed ; 3 Provide verification or copy of any judgment ( if applicable ) 4.All communication attempts to resolve the issue prior to reporting to collections 5. Proof that you are licensed to collect debts in Texas. 
I received a letter from them around XX/XX/XXXX that included XXXX the amount of debt, and 2. the name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed.

They did not provided : verification or copy of any judgment, all communication attempts to resolve the issue prior to reporting to collections or proof that they are licensed to collect debts in TX. 
Prior to receiving the letter from Innovative Recovery dated, XX/XX/XXXX, I checked my mailing address on or about XX/XX/XXXX. I found in the mailbox a letter from IR, dated, XX/XX/XXXX. It is important to note that they flagged my credit and reported to the credit bureaus prior to the 30 days given to respond in their initial letter. 
Please note that I officially moved from the property whom IR is collecting on behalf of XX/XX/XXXX due to issues on the property and health reason as well as work. I was working out of state and provided the rental company the forwarding address and expressly requested that all communication be delivered to an address in AR. I paid my rent timely and for over 14 months, and was only 3 months from completing the lease. I requested that any final bills ect ... and/or to confirm with me whether or not the reletting fees would be waived due to ongoing issues on the property. Including but not limited to a civil action that I filed against them for intimidation etc.. When I did not hear from the property XX/XX/XXXX- XX/XX/XXXX, I presumed that the property considered our relationship to be an even wash. Nonetheless, to learn that they never mailed me any communication and forwarded the wrong address to the debt collector for collection activities seems deliberate. The actions of both the property and the debt collector has caused by credit scores to decrease over XXXX points, resulting in a fair credit rating when I have had good credit standing. 

In spite of my previous request to IR to cease contacting me and collection activity, due to the bonafide dispute ( filed civil case ), I have received several calls, and voicemails attempting to collect this debt. Again on XX/XX/XXXX, the company flagged my credit profile causing negative impact on my credit rating. 
IR debt practices seem unethical, and failure to report to the credit bureaus of the bonafide dispute is a misrepresentation of the actual allege debt. As a consumer whom previously had a good credit rating and pay my debts on time, I feel harassed, and intimidated by their practices.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX I stopped for gas at a XXXX. The XXXX XXXX  did not have a tap to pay option. I had to enter my debit card and PIN number to start fueling. I then continued driving on to my destination. On XX/XX/XXXX a charge from both XXXX and XXXX XXXX was posted simultaneously to my checking account with a transaction date of XX/XX/XXXX. The XXXX charge was {$310.00} and the XXXX XXXX charge was {$130.00}. 
When I looked up the XXXX and XXXX XXXX, based on the store number from the posted transactions, it happen to be the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  to the XXXX XXXX  XXXX  and XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

I called Wells Fargo and Disputed the charges, since I did not make those charges. After getting gas I continued driving. I had my kids in the car with me. Any mom would know that I would definitely remember getting my kids in and out of their car seats twice to go into stores. I also would have noticed the {$310.00} worth of groceries from XXXX and the {$130.00} supplies from XXXX XXXX. Also to mention, I did not even stop at the XXXX XXXX or XXXX. Therefore, theres no way I made those charges. 

Wells Fargo immediately refunded my account {$450.00} during the investigation. 

Now 3 months later the {$450.00} was taken OUT of my account by Wells Fargo. Wells Fargo denied the claim 3 months later. They did not provide any reason as to what evidence or reasons they have to deny the claim except for stating they were authorized charges. 

I kept asking what basis they were using to determine that the charges were authorized charges. They provided no answer. I, the owner of the account, did not use my debit card at XXXX or XXXX XXXX that day. Neither did my husband, who would be the only other authorized user. Therefore, they were not authorized charges. 

Wells Fargo would not explain anything to us. They said there was nothing else left to do. I guess they are assuming I am suppose to let someone take my {$450.00} and be ok with it? 

What happened is someone stole my card information when I inserted my card at XXXX. They took the card information and used it at XXXX XXXX and XXXX. Now Wells Fargo is completely supporting someone else using our money. It was our money we worked hard for and we trusted in WellsFargo to keep safe. 

Those were my last XXXX transactions with that debit card number since I canceled my card immediately.

Consumer complaint narrative:
This is a follow-up complaint continued from the original complaint ID XXXX. 

Unfortunately, I find this case should be re-opened. I received the company 's response ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and confirmed that they issued the correct amount of mileage in the statement ( XX/XX/XXXX ). Because this was out of the usual processing period, I called US Bank and talked to the rep. The rep also stated that it should have been transferred to the XXXX account last week and put me on hold to speak to the supervisor. After 15 minutes on hold, listening to the background music, the rep returned and said that her supervisor needed more time with the research and asked for another holding. I waited for another 10-15 minutes. Then, suddenly, the background music changed. I thought it was strange, but I kept waiting. Finally, someone came back. But, she was not the same rep, but another rep. This new rep asked me why I called. What?!?!??! So, while on hold, my call was transferred to another person in another department. This new person had no idea why I was waiting on the phone and asked me my previous concern. I did not think it was fair to repeat the whole thing again after spending 30 minutes, so I told her that I would continue this with CFPB.

I've had previous experiences with some reps saying I would be transferred to someone else in another department or I would get a return call later time. But, something I had today was a new experience. They should have been honest if they couldn't find the solution and get my phone number or email information so they could contact me later instead of transferring a customer without notification. 

Basically, this issue still needs to be resolved. The bank pretended to fulfill its responsibility of issuing the promised mileage. However, it failed to transfer the mileage to the linked mileage program properly. Furthermore, it shook off the customer who inquired about this matter by silently transferring the call to another random rep to repeat the never-ending cycle. Typical.

Product: Money transfer, virtual currency, or money service
Consumer complaint narrative:
Page XXXX of XXXX XX/XX/year> US Bank is obliged to take some action if it is sufficiently aware of a real possibility that a fraud may be being perpetuated. If you don't question its customers instructions or raise the possibility of a scam with the customer in these circumstances, it may be liable if the red flags indicate the customer is : particularly vulnerable, or if the possibility of fraud was serious or real, not just suspected. There are some recommendations to organizations for protecting customers from financial harm that might occur as a result of fraud or financial abuse ; and gives guidance on how to recognize customers who might be at risk, how to assess the potential risks to the individual and how to take the necessary actions to prevent or minimize financial harm. These recommendations are established as a general principle, the organization should deliver a service that : XXXX ) Takes a proactive approach to minimizing risks, impact and incidences of financial harm and it sets out systems and tools for the prevention and detection of fraud and financial abuse. As a general point, it says organizations should ensure that all systems are developed using technologies and methodologies that are effective in the prevention of fraud and financial abuse, through authorized and unauthorized payments, thereby minimizing the risk of financial harm to customers. As regards to the detection of fraud and financial abuse, it says the organization : A ) should have measures in place across all payment channels and products to detect suspicious transactions or activities that might indicate fraud or financial abuse. It then lists the following examples of suspicious activity on customer accounts : a. multiple cheque books; b. sudden increased spending ; XXXX transfers to other accounts ; d. multiple password attempts ; e. logins from new devices, multiple geographical locations ; f. sudden changes to the operation of the account ; Unusual transactions are transactions whose amount, characteristics and frequency bear no relation to the economic activity of the customer, exceed normal market parameters or have no apparent legal justification. g. a withdrawal or payment for a large amount ; h. a payment or series of payments to a new payee ; i. financial activity that matches a known method of fraud or financial abuse. 
Page XXXX of XXXX XX/XX/year> B ) organizations should have a process in place to ensure that staff make contact with the customer to verify the financial activity, challenge its authenticity, explain the nature of the suspected or detected fraud and discuss an appropriate plan of action. US Bank are yet to show, or otherwise provide me with, a compelling argument that their wide-ranging experience and wealth of specialist knowledge in detecting transactional anomalies were not sufficient to avert the fraud at issue. By contrast, I have provided a multitude of sound and powerful reasons by which requiring their involvement has not only been pressingly relevant but also eminently reasonable and well-justified. Rather than empathizing with and undertaking substantial efforts to convey their knowledge of the existence of such regulations abroad and thereafter use it to protect and proactively relieve the plight of consumers who have been cheated out of their money and whose role in society is properly fulfilled, positively contributing to local economic growth, development and sustainability US Bank adopts a rather insouciant attitude toward my financial predicament portrayed herein. I am deeply convinced that the disastrous results that I have previously elaborated upon will continue to ensue if no responsibility is adopted by US Bank in relation to this matter. I have also thoroughly detailed why they can not simply dismiss this problem by strictly adhering to legal technicalities which, after careful reflection, struck me as being nothing more than self-interest. Indeed, it seems to me utterly unfair to disregard fragile, sensitive, and vulnerable consumers who are afflicted by such allegedly malevolent acts, thereby keeping an unjust status-quo that is corrupting our society at its core. Conclusion : Based on my analysis, and as confirmed by various authorities concerned with such matters, there is abundant evidence that forward-thinking financial institutions ought to take reasonable steps to forestall fraud, or at least mitigate its risk by using an effective risk management system, demonstrating their undisputed ability to responsibly and pre-emptively respond to questionable transactions in the digital arena. The use of such systems, largely based on newly adopted technologies aimed at effectively navigating the evolving threat landscape, is only one of a number of possible endeavors undertaken in this connection, alongside the application of past knowledge and experience related to popular fraudulent practices. Astonishingly, I am pondering how it is that, despite being shown that US Banks business conduct was insufficient insofar as background checks are concerned, they keep refuting their indisputable role and responsibility in connection with the matter herein discussed. The points that I have hitherto made are too crucial to be taken lightly. US Banks non-observance of the fundamental principles of justice that is, to completely overlook and not even remotely try to mitigate the suffering of vulnerable consumers is inexcusable given the size of the establishment and the vast resources at its disposal as the direct result of the patronage of clients like myself. If it was, indeed, solely my responsibility, we must then believe at least one of the following clauses : a ) financial institutions have absolutely no role whatsoever in preventing and detecting fraud, b ) the fraud in question was not reasonably foreseeable, or c ) the transactions in question Page 6 of XXXX XX/XX/year> were not sufficiently alarming. It is extremely unfortunate that US Bank pushes quite hard for me to believe all three of these thingsdespite evidence to the contrary. In summary, I respectively ask your organization to consider my points, given your personal and companywide obligation to provide a fair and reasonable investigation into the complaint. I look forward to your input and would gladly cooperate to reach a fair and reasonable outcome. Thank you. XXXX XXXX XXXX THE REMAINDER OF THIS PAGE IS INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Complaint for Removal of Inaccurate Account Information and Compensation Request Re : Unauthorized Data Reporting and Violation of Consumer Rights under the FCRA Dear [ Credit Reporting Agency or Data Furnisher 's Name ], I am writing to formally dispute and demand the immediate removal of inaccurate information from my credit report in accordance with my rights as a federally protected consumer under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). Additionally, I am officially opting out of any and all authorizations I may have previously grantedwhether written, unwritten, verbal, or non-verbalregarding the reporting of information that does not comply with federal law.

Legal Basis for Removal Pursuant to 16 CFR Part 313 ( Privacy of Consumer Financial Information ) and 16 CFR Part 433 ( Preservation of Consumers ' Claims and Defenses ), I am asserting the following : 16 CFR Part 313 mandates the protection of consumer financial information and restricts the unauthorized sharing of personal data.

16 CFR Part 433 ensures that consumers ' claims and defenses are preserved, prohibiting the inclusion of unfair or deceptive acts or practices by data furnishers in credit reporting. Specifically, 16 CFR 433.2 ( a ) requires any holder of a consumer credit contract to be subject to all claims and defenses the debtor could assert against the original seller.

Unauthorized Reporting of Charge-Off Accounts Under FCRA regulations, a charge-off should not appear on my credit report as it represents a certificate of indebtedness or an accounting adjustment, which in legal terms can be categorized as income and therefore should not be reported to credit bureaus. The report of this charge-off represents an inaccurate portrayal of my financial standing and an unauthorized disclosure of my private information.

Request for Deletion and Compensation I hereby demand the following : Immediate Deletion of any charge-offs or similarly misclassified accounts that violate 16 CFR Parts 313 and 433, FCRA, and the Truth in Lending Act.

Compensation for the violation of my rights as a consumer due to the unauthorized reporting of inaccurate information. The impact of this erroneous reporting has affected my creditworthiness and caused me undue stress and inconvenience.

Confirmation in writing that all inaccurate and unauthorized information has been removed from my credit file and details regarding the compensation process.

Notice of Preservation of Consumer Claims and Defenses As per 16 CFR 433.2, please note the following provision applies : NOTICEANY HOLDER OF THIS CONSUMER CREDIT CONTRACT IS SUBJECT TO ALL CLAIMS AND DEFENSES WHICH THE DEBTOR COULD ASSERT AGAINST THE SELLER OF GOODS OR SERVICES OBTAINED PURSUANT HERETO OR WITH THE PROCEEDS HEREOF. RECOVERY HEREUNDER BY THE DEBTOR SHALL NOT EXCEED AMOUNTS PAID BY THE DEBTOR HEREUNDER.

Failure to respond to this request may lead to further action to enforce my rights as a consumer, including but not limited to legal avenues.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I expect confirmation of these changes and a response regarding compensation within 30 days, as per the FCRA 's required response timeline. 

XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX

( XX/XX/XXXX, ch. XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ; XXXX XXXX, XXXX, ch. XXXX, title XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ; XX/XX/XXXX, ch. XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ; Pub. XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ; Pub. XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ; Pub. XXXX XXXX, XXXX ( a ), XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ; Pub. XXXX XXXX, title XXXX, XXXX ( a ), XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX. ) XXXX XXXX Code XXXX - Unfair practices XXXX XXXX Notes XXXX | next A debt collector may not use unfair or unconscionable means to collect or attempt to collect any debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : ( 1 ) The collection of any amount ( including any interest, fee, charge, or expense incidental to the principal obligation ) unless such amount is expressly authorized by the agreement creating the debt or permitted by law.

( 2 ) The acceptance by a debt collector from any person of a check or other payment instrument postdated by more than five days unless such person is notified in writing of the debt collectors intent to deposit such check or instrument not more than ten nor less than three business days prior to such deposit.

( 3 ) The solicitation by a debt collector of any postdated check or other postdated payment instrument for the purpose of threatening or instituting criminal prosecution.

( 4 ) Depositing or threatening to deposit any postdated check or other postdated payment instrument prior to the date on such check or instrument.

( 5 ) Causing charges to be made to any person for communications by concealment of the true purpose of the communication. Such charges include, but are not limited to, collect telephone calls and telegram fees.

( 6 ) Taking or threatening to take any nonjudicial action to effect dispossession or disablement of property if ( A ) there is no present right to possession of the property claimed as collateral through an enforceable security interest ; ( B ) there is no present intention to take possession of the property ; or ( C ) the property is exempt by law from such dispossession or disablement.

( 7 ) Communicating with a consumer regarding a debt by post card.

( 8 ) Using any language or symbol, other than the debt collectors address, on any envelope when communicating with a consumer by use of the mails or by telegram, except that a debt collector may use his business name if such name does not indicate that he is in the debt collection business. 
( Pub. XXXX XXXX, title XXXX, XXXX, as added Pub. XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX. ) XXXX General disclosure requirements. 
( a ) Form of disclosures ( 1 ) General.

( i ) The creditor shall make the disclosures required by this subpart clearly and conspicuously.

( ii ) The creditor shall make the disclosures required by this subpart in writing, in a form that the consumer may keep, except that : ( A ) The following disclosures need not be written : Disclosures under 1026.6 ( b ) ( 3 ) of charges that are imposed as part of an open-end ( not home-secured ) plan that are not required to be disclosed under 1026.6 ( b ) ( 2 ) and related disclosures of charges under 1026.9 ( c ) ( 2 ) ( iii ) ( B ) ; disclosures under 1026.9 ( c ) ( 2 ) ( vi ) ; disclosures under 1026.9 ( d ) when a finance charge is imposed at the time of the transaction ; and disclosures under 1026.56 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( i ). 

( B ) The following disclosures need not be in a retainable form : Disclosures that need not be written under paragraph ( a ) ( XXXX ) ( ii ) ( A ) of this section ; disclosures for credit and charge card applications and solicitations under 1026.60 ; home-equity disclosures under 1026.40 ( d ) ; the alternative summary billing-rights statement under 1026.9 ( a ) ( 2 ) ; the credit and charge card renewal disclosures required under 1026.9 ( e ) ; and the payment requirements under 1026.10 ( b ), except as provided in 1026.7 ( b ) ( 13 ).

( iii ) The disclosures required by this subpart may be provided to the consumer in electronic form, subject to compliance with the consumer consent and other applicable provisions of the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act ( E-Sign Act ) ( 15 U.S.C. 7001 et seq. ). The disclosures required by 1026.60, 1026.40, and 1026.16 may be provided to the consumer in electronic form without regard to the consumer consent or other provisions of the E-Sign Act in the circumstances set forth in those sections.

( 2 ) Terminology.

( i ) Terminology used in providing the disclosures required by this subpart shall be consistent.

( ii ) For home-equity plans subject to 1026.40, the terms finance charge and annual percentage rate, when required to be disclosed with a corresponding amount or percentage rate, shall be more conspicuous than any other required disclosure. The terms need not be more conspicuous when used for periodic statement disclosures under 1026.7 ( a ) ( 4 ) and for advertisements under 1026.16.

( iii ) If disclosures are required to be presented in a tabular format pursuant to paragraph ( a ) ( 3 ) of this section, the term penalty APR shall be used, as applicable. The term penalty APR need not be used in reference to the annual percentage rate that applies with the loss of a promotional rate, assuming the annual percentage rate that applies is not greater than the annual percentage rate that would have applied at the end of the promotional period ; or if the annual percentage rate that applies with the loss of a promotional rate is a variable rate, the annual percentage rate is calculated using the same index and margin as would have been used to calculate the annual percentage rate that would have applied at the end of the promotional period. If credit insurance or debt cancellation or debt suspension coverage is required as part of the plan, the term required shall be used and the program shall be identified by its name. If an annual percentage rate is required to be presented in a tabular format pursuant to paragraph ( a ) ( 3 ) ( i ) or ( a ) ( 3 ) ( iii ) of this section, the term fixed, or a similar term, may not be used to describe such rate unless the creditor also specifies a time period that the rate will be fixed and the rate will not increase during that period, or if no such time period is provided, the rate will not increase while the plan is open.

( 3 ) Specific formats.

( i ) Certain disclosures for credit and charge card applications and solicitations must be provided in a tabular format in accordance with the requirements of 1026.60 ( a ) ( 2 ).

( ii ) Certain disclosures for home-equity plans must precede other disclosures and must be given in accordance with the requirements of 1026.40 ( a ).

( iii ) Certain account-opening disclosures must be provided in a tabular format in accordance with the requirements of 1026.6 ( b ) ( 1 ).

( iv ) Certain disclosures provided on periodic statements must be grouped together in accordance with the requirements of 1026.7 ( b ) ( 6 ) and ( b ) ( 13 ).

( v ) Certain disclosures provided on periodic statements must be given in accordance with the requirements of 1026.7 ( b ) ( 12 ).

( vi ) Certain disclosures accompanying checks that access a credit card account must be provided in a tabular format in accordance with the requirements of 1026.9 ( b ) ( 3 ).

( vii ) Certain disclosures provided in a change-in-terms notice must be provided in a tabular format in accordance with the requirements of 1026.9 ( c ) ( 2 ) ( iv ) ( D ).

( viii ) Certain disclosures provided when a rate is increased due to delinquency, default or as a penalty must be provided in a tabular format in accordance with the requirements of 1026.9 ( g ) ( 3 ) ( ii ).

( b ) Time of disclosures ( 1 ) Account-opening disclosures ( i ) General rule. The creditor shall furnish account-opening disclosures required by 1026.6 before the first transaction is made under the plan.

( ii ) Charges imposed as part of an open-end ( not home-secured ) plan. Charges that are imposed as part of an open-end ( not home-secured ) plan and are not required to be disclosed under 1026.6 ( b ) ( 2 ) may be disclosed after account opening but before the consumer agrees to pay or becomes obligated to pay for the charge, provided they are disclosed at a time and in a manner that a consumer would be likely to notice them. This provision does not apply to charges imposed as part of a home-equity plan subject to the requirements of 1026.40.

( iii ) Telephone purchases. Disclosures required by 1026.6 may be provided as soon as reasonably practicable after the first transaction if : ( A ) The first transaction occurs when a consumer contacts a merchant by telephone to purchase goods and at the same time the consumer accepts an offer to finance the purchase by establishing an open-end plan with the merchant or third-party creditor ; ( B ) The merchant or third-party creditor permits consumers to return any goods financed under the plan and provides consumers with a sufficient time to reject the plan and return the goods free of cost after the merchant or third-party creditor has provided the written disclosures required by 1026.6 ; and ( C ) The consumer 's right to reject the plan and return the goods is disclosed to the consumer as a part of the offer to finance the purchase.

( iv ) Membership fees ( A ) General. In general, a creditor may not collect any fee before account-opening disclosures are provided. A creditor may collect, or obtain the consumer 's agreement to pay, membership fees, including application fees excludable from the finance charge under 1026.4 ( c ) ( 1 ), before providing account-opening disclosures if, after receiving the disclosures, the consumer may reject the plan and have no obligation to pay these fees ( including application fees ) or any other fee or charge. A membership fee for purposes of this paragraph has the same meaning as a fee for the issuance or availability of credit described in 1026.60 ( b ) ( 2 ). If the consumer rejects the plan, the creditor must promptly refund the membership fee if it has been paid, or take other action necessary to ensure the consumer is not obligated to pay that fee or any other fee or charge.

( B ) Home-equity plans. Creditors offering home-equity plans subject to the requirements of 1026.40 are not subject to the requirements of paragraph ( b ) ( 1 ) ( iv ) ( A ) of this section.

( v ) Application fees. A creditor may collect an application fee excludable from the finance charge under 1026.4 ( c ) ( 1 ) before providing account-opening disclosures. However, if a consumer rejects the plan after receiving account-opening disclosures, the consumer must have no obligation to pay such an application fee, or if the fee was paid, it must be refunded. See 1026.5 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( iv ) ( A ).

( 2 ) Periodic statements ( i ) Statement required. The creditor shall mail or deliver a periodic statement as required by 1026.7 for each billing cycle at the end of which an account has a debit or credit balance of more than {$1.00} or on which a finance charge has been imposed. A periodic statement need not be sent for an account if the creditor deems it uncollectible, if delinquency collection proceedings have been instituted, if the creditor has charged off the account in accordance with loan-loss provisions and will not charge any additional fees or interest on the account, or if furnishing the statement would violate Federal law.

( ii ) Timing requirements ( A ) Credit card accounts under an open-end ( not home-secured ) consumer credit plan. For credit card accounts under an open-end ( not home-secured ) consumer credit plan, a card issuer must adopt reasonable procedures designed to ensure that : ( 1 ) Periodic statements are mailed or delivered at least 21 days prior to the payment due date disclosed on the statement pursuant to 1026.7 ( b ) ( 11 ) ( i ) ( A ) ; and ( 2 ) The card issuer does not treat as late for any purpose a required minimum periodic payment received by the card issuer within 21 days after mailing or delivery of the periodic statement disclosing the due date for that payment.

( B ) Open-end consumer credit plans. For accounts under an open-end consumer credit plan, a creditor must adopt reasonable procedures designed to ensure that : ( 1 ) If a grace period applies to the account : ( i ) Periodic statements are mailed or delivered at least 21 days prior to the date on which the grace period expires; and ( ii ) The creditor does not impose finance charges as a result of the loss of the grace period if a payment that satisfies the terms of the grace period is received by the creditor within 21 days after mailing or delivery of the periodic statement.

( 2 ) Regardless of whether a grace period applies to the account : ( i ) Periodic statements are mailed or delivered at least 14 days prior to the date on which the required minimum periodic payment must be received in order to avoid being treated as late for any purpose; and ( ii ) The creditor does not treat as late for any purpose a required minimum periodic payment received by the creditor within 14 days after mailing or delivery of the periodic statement.

( 3 ) For purposes of paragraph ( b ) ( 2 ) ( ii ) ( B ) of this section, grace period means a period within which any credit extended may be repaid without incurring a finance charge due to a periodic interest rate.

( 3 ) Credit and charge card application and solicitation disclosures. The card issuer shall furnish the disclosures for credit and charge card applications and solicitations in accordance with the timing requirements of 1026.60.

( 4 ) Home-equity plans. Disclosures for home-equity plans shall be made in accordance with the timing requirements of 1026.40 ( b ).

( c ) Basis of disclosures and use of estimates. Disclosures shall reflect the terms of the legal obligation between the parties. If any information necessary for accurate disclosure is unknown to the creditor, it shall make the disclosure based on the best information reasonably available and shall state clearly that the disclosure is an estimate.

( d ) Multiple creditors ; multiple consumers. If the credit plan involves more than one creditor, only one set of disclosures shall be given, and the creditors shall agree among themselves which creditor must comply with the requirements that this part imposes on any or all of them. If there is more than one consumer, the disclosures may be made to any consumer who is primarily liable on the account. If the right of rescission under 1026.15 is applicable, however, the disclosures required by 1026.6 and 1026.15 ( b ) shall be made to each consumer having the right to rescind.

( e ) Effect of subsequent events. If a disclosure becomes inaccurate because of an event that occurs after the creditor mails or delivers the disclosures, the resulting inaccuracy is not a violation of this part, although new disclosures may be required under 1026.9 ( c ).

15 U.S. Code 6802 - Obligations with respect to disclosures of personal information U.S. Code Notes prev | next ( a ) Notice requirements Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, a financial institution may not, directly or through any affiliate, disclose to a nonaffiliated third party any nonpublic personal information, unless such financial institution provides or has provided to the consumer a notice that complies with section 6803 of this title.

( b ) Opt out ( 1 ) In general A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless ( A ) such financial institution clearly and conspicuously discloses to the consumer, in writing or in electronic form or other form permitted by the regulations prescribed under section 6804 of this title, that such information may be disclosed to such third party ; ( B ) the consumer is given the opportunity, before the time that such information is initially disclosed, to direct that such information not be disclosed to such third party ; and ( C ) the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option.

( 2 ) Exception This subsection shall not prevent a financial institution from providing nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party to perform services for or functions on behalf of the financial institution, including marketing of the financial institutions own products or services, or financial products or services offered pursuant to joint agreements between two or more financial institutions that comply with the requirements imposed by the regulations prescribed under section 6804 of this title, if the financial institution fully discloses the providing of such information and enters into a contractual agreement with the third party that requires the third party to maintain the confidentiality of such information.

( c ) Limits on reuse of information Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, a nonaffiliated third party that receives from a financial institution nonpublic personal information under this section shall not, directly or through an affiliate of such receiving third party, disclose such information to any other person that is a nonaffiliated third party of both the financial institution and such receiving third party, unless such disclosure would be lawful if made directly to such other person by the financial institution.

( d ) Limitations on the sharing of account number information for marketing purposes A financial institution shall not disclose, other than to a consumer reporting agency, an account number or similar form of access number or access code for a credit card account, deposit account, or transaction account of a consumer to any nonaffiliated third party for use in telemarketing, direct mail marketing, or other marketing through electronic mail to the consumer.

( e ) General exceptions Subsections ( a ) and ( b ) shall not prohibit the disclosure of nonpublic personal information ( 1 ) as necessary to effect, administer, or enforce a transaction requested or authorized by the consumer, or in connection with ( A ) servicing or processing a financial product or service requested or authorized by the consumer ; ( B ) maintaining or servicing the consumers account with the financial institution, or with another entity as part of a private label credit card program or other extension of credit on behalf of such entity ; or ( C ) a proposed or actual securitization, secondary market sale ( including sales of servicing rights ), or similar transaction related to a transaction of the consumer ; ( 2 ) with the consent or at the direction of the consumer ; ( 3 ) ( A ) to protect the confidentiality or security of the financial institutions records pertaining to the consumer, the service or product, or the transaction therein ; ( B ) to protect against or prevent actual or potential fraud, unauthorized transactions, claims, or other liability ; ( C ) for required institutional risk control, or for resolving customer disputes or inquiries ; ( D ) to persons holding a legal or beneficial interest relating to the consumer ; or ( E ) to persons acting in a fiduciary or representative capacity on behalf of the consumer ; ( 4 ) to provide information to insurance rate advisory organizations, guaranty funds or agencies, applicable rating agencies of the financial institution, persons assessing the institutions compliance with industry standards, and the institutions attorneys, accountants, and auditors ; ( 5 ) to the extent specifically permitted or required under other provisions of law and in accordance with the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978 [ 12 U.S.C. 3401 et seq. ], to law enforcement agencies ( including the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection [ 1 ] a Federal functional regulator, the Secretary of the Treasury with respect to subchapter II of chapter 53 of title 31, and chapter 2 of title I of Public Law 91508 ( 12 U.S.C. 19511959 ), a State insurance authority, or the Federal Trade Commission ), self-regulatory organizations, or for an investigation on a matter related to public safety ; ( 6 ) ( A ) to a consumer reporting agency in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act [ 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. ], or ( B ) from a consumer report reported by a consumer reporting agency ; ( 7 ) in connection with a proposed or actual sale, merger, transfer, or exchange of all or a portion of a business or operating unit if the disclosure of nonpublic personal information concerns solely consumers of such business or unit; or ( 8 ) to comply with Federal, State, or local laws, rules, and other applicable legal requirements ; to comply with a properly authorized civil, criminal, or regulatory investigation or subpoena or summons by Federal, State, or local authorities ; or to respond to judicial process or government regulatory authorities having jurisdiction over the financial institution for examination, compliance, or other purposes as authorized by law. 
( Pub. XXXX XXXX, title XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ; Pub. XXXX XXXX, title X, XXXX ( XXXX ), XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX. ) XXXX. TENDER OF PAYMENT. 
Primary tabs ( a ) If tender of payment of an obligation to pay an instrument is made to a person entitled to enforce the instrument, the effect of tender is governed by principles of law applicable to tender of payment under a simple contract. 

( b ) If tender of payment of an obligation to pay an instrument is made to a person entitled to enforce the instrument and the tender is refused, there is discharge, to the extent of the amount of the tender, of the obligation of an indorser or accommodation party having a right of recourse with respect to the obligation to which the tender relates. 

( c ) If tender of payment of an amount due on an instrument is made to a person entitled to enforce the instrument, the obligation of the obligor to pay interest after the due date on the amount tendered is XXXX. If presentment is required with respect to an instrument and the obligor is able and ready to pay on the due date at every place of payment stated in the instrument, the obligor is deemed to have made tender of payment on the due date to the person entitled to enforce the instrument. 

XXXX. PAYMENT. up XXXX. DISCHARGE BY CANCELLATION OR RENUNCIATION. 
XXXX. XXXX of XXXX XXXX. 
Primary tabs XXXX contract or duty within the XXXX XXXX XXXX imposes an obligation of good faith in its performance and enforcement. 

XXXX. Course of XXXX, XXXX of Dealing, and Usage of XXXX. up XXXX. Remedies to be Liberally Administered. 
XXXX. ACCORD AND SATISFACTION BY USE OF INSTRUMENT. 
Primary tabs ( a ) If a person against whom a claim is asserted proves that ( i ) that person in good faith tendered an instrument to the claimant as full satisfaction of the claim, ( ii ) the amount of the claim was unliquidated or subject to a bona fide dispute, and ( iii ) the claimant obtained payment of the instrument, the following subsections apply. 

( b ) Unless subsection ( c ) applies, the claim is discharged if the person against whom the claim is asserted proves that the instrument or an accompanying written communication contained a conspicuous statement to the effect that the instrument was tendered as full satisfaction of the claim. 

( c ) Subject to subsection ( d ), a claim is not discharged under subsection ( b ) if either of the following applies : ( XXXX ) The claimant, if an organization, proves that ( i ) within a reasonable time before the tender, the claimant sent a conspicuous statement to the person against whom the claim is asserted that communications concerning disputed debts, including an instrument tendered as full satisfaction of a debt, are to be sent to a designated person, office, or place, and ( ii ) the instrument or accompanying communication was not received by that designated person, office, or place. 

( XXXX ) The claimant, whether or not an organization, proves that within 90 days after payment of the instrument, the claimant tendered repayment of the amount of the instrument to the person against whom the claim is asserted. This paragraph does not apply if the claimant is an organization that that sent a statement complying with paragraph ( 1 ) ( i ).

( d ) A claim is discharged if the person against whom the claim is asserted proves that within a reasonable time before collection of the instrument was initiated, the claimant, or an agent of the claimant having direct responsibility with respect to the disputed obligation, knew that the instrument was tendered in full satisfaction of the claim.

Subject : Complaint Regarding Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) I am submitting this complaint regarding violations of my rights as a consumer under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) by Experian Despite my previous correspondence, which requested the removal of the above-mentioned account due to inaccuracies and failure to validate the information as required by law, Experian has not conducted a proper investigation nor provided the required documentation. 
Reasons for Complaint : 1. Violation of the FCRA : o Investigation Requirements ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) : Your verification response did not include a sufficient description of the investigation process, as required by the FCRA. You failed to adhere to the obligation to provide a thorough and detailed account of the steps taken to verify the information.

o Permissible Purposes ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( 2 ) ) : The information provided did not comply with the permissible purposes outlined in the FCRA. The verification process failed to meet the established standards for handling and reporting information. 
o Privacy Rights ( 15 U.S.C. 1681a ( 4 ) ) : The continued inclusion of this bankruptcy record and associated accounts infringes upon my privacy rights. The failure to follow appropriate procedures for handling sensitive information constitutes a violation of this section.

o Description of Investigation ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( 7 ) ) : Credit reporting agencies are obligated to provide a description of the investigation within 15 days of receiving a dispute. To date, I have not received this required information. 
o Invocation of 15 U.S.C. 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( a ) and 15 U.S.C. 609 ( a ) ( 2 ) : I am invoking these provisions to request the removal of this account and to demand proof of its verification. The failure to complete this verification constitutes an abuse of my rights.

2. Violation of the TILA : o Disclosure Requirements : Experian failed to provide accurate and timely disclosures regarding the account status, breaching the TILA requirements.

3. Federal Consumer Protections : o Title 15, Chapter 41 : The failure to provide adequate proof and the apparent disregard for my rights under the FCRA indicate a violation of federal consumer protection laws.

o Public Law 91-506, Title VI, Section 611, Subsections A-D : This law stipulates the procedures for the removal of inaccurate or incomplete information from credit reports. The response and verification process did not comply with these provisions, necessitating the removal of the bankruptcy record.

Immediate Action Requested : Delete Immediately for Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : 1. Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX Account Number:XXXX Present below the inaccurate information persistently affecting my credit report.
